ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Surety bonds required; premiums. 
(a)  Surety bonds shall be furnished as required by the city council. 
(b)  Premiums for surety bonds furnished to the city shall be paid out of city funds. If additional bonds are required from time to time to cover the collection of county and state taxes as prescribed by law, such bonds shall be furnished and the premiums paid by the city. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 9, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-3) 
Charter reference- Surety bonds, § 5.4. 
Secs. 2-2-2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-26. - Date of regular meetings. 
    Unless otherwise provided by the council, the council shall meet on the first and third Mondays of each month, which meetings shall be regular stated meetings. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 2, 9-19-57; Code 1968, § 2-1) 
Charter reference- Regular stated meetings required, § 6.1. 
Sec. 2-27. - Time, place of meetings. 
    The council shall determine by resolution the time and place of regular and special meetings of the council. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 3, 9-19-57; Code 1968, § 2-2) 
Charter reference- Authority to designate meeting time and place, § 6.1. 
Secs. 2-28-2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 795 , § 1, adopted Dec. 18, 2017, repealed the former Div. 1, §§ 2-51-2-53, and enacted a new Div. 1 as set out herein. The former Div. 1 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete derivation of the former provisions. 

Sec. 2-51. - Combination of offices and annual appointment of officers and deputies. 
(a)  The following offices are combined in the office of city manager pursuant to the provisions of the City Charter: city administrator, city clerk, city treasurer, city assessor, city superintendent, department of public works director, building official, parks and recreation director, and pollution control superintendent. Once appointed, individuals holding these at-will positions shall serve indefinitely, in accordance with the personnel policies of the City of Saline, as amended. 
(b)  In accordance with an organizational plan approved by the city council, the city manager shall appoint directors, deputies, and other city staff to carry out the functions the city manager deems necessary. Those persons appointed by the city manager shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(c)  The city council shall appoint all department heads of the City of Saline. Those persons appointed by the city council shall serve at the pleasure of the city council. Positions designated as department heads include the following: city administrator, city clerk, city treasurer, city assessor, city superintendent, department of public works director, parks and recreation director, and pollution control superintendent. 
(d)  The city manager shall set the salaries of the directors, department heads, and deputies appointed pursuant to this section. The directors, department heads, and deputies appointed pursuant to this section shall be under the supervision of, and report to, the city manager. 
(e)  The police chief will be appointed by the city council and shall serve at the pleasure of the city council. The police chief shall be under the supervision of, and report to, the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 791 , § 1, 6-19-17; Ord. No. 795 , § 1, 12-18-17) 
Sec. 2-52. - Salary of city manager and police chief. 
(a)  The salary of the city manager and police chief shall be set, and may be modified from time to time, by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Payment of fringe benefits to the city manager and police chief, and any additional terms and conditions of employment, shall be as set forth in an employment agreement. 
(Ord. No. 795 , § 1, 12-18-17) 
Secs. 2-53-2-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-66. - Office created. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of section 4.4 of the charter, there is hereby created the office of city administrator which shall be filled by council appointment in accordance with the provisions of section 4.4 of the charter. 
(Code 1968, § 2-11; Ord. No. 350, § 1, 7-7-80) 
Sec. 2-67. - Administrative position; qualifications. 
    The city administrator shall be the administrative agent of the city and shall perform such duties of his office as may be delegated to him by the council and the mayor, and shall be accountable to the council and the mayor for the performance of his duties. He shall be chosen on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications. 
(Code 1968, § 2-12; Ord. No. 350, § 2, 7-7-80) 
Sec. 2-68. - Duties. 
    The duties of the city administrator shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Direct, supervise and coordinate the work of all existing city departments and staff and such additional administrative units as the council may from time to time designate. 
(2)  Assume the duties of any administrative officer who is required to be appointed upon his recommendation, when so directed by the council. 
(3)  Maintain an employment office and central personnel service for the several administrative units and make recommendations for appointment to the council. 
(4)  Keep informed concerning the administration of the several administrative units; to that end, the heads of all administrative units shall furnish him such information and periodical or special reports as he may deem necessary. 
(5)  In case of conflict of authority between administrative units, or in case of absence of administrative authority occasioned by inadequacy of charter or ordinance provisions, resolve the conflict or supply the necessary authority, so far as may be consistent with law, the charter, and the ordinances of the city, and direct the necessary action to be taken in conformance therewith, making a full report immediately to the mayor and the council of the problem and his action thereon, with his recommendation for corrective legislation. 
(6)  Attend all open meetings of the council-with the right to take part in all discussions, but without the right to vote-and such executive sessions as otherwise requested. 
(7)  Recommend to the mayor and the council, from time to time, such measures as he deems necessary or appropriate for the improvement of the city or its services. 
(8)  Possess such further powers and perform such additional duties as may be granted to or required of him, from time to time, by the council, so far as may be consistent with state law and the charter. 
(9)  Do everything necessary and proper to execute the foregoing powers in accordance with the policies adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1968, § 2-13; Ord. No. 350, § 3, 7-7-80; Ord. No. 424, § 1, 2-1-88) 
Sec. 2-69. - Authority. 
    The city administrator shall have the following authority in relation to department heads: 
(1)  If there is a vacancy in any department head position responsible to the city administrator, the city administrator may assume all the functions of the department head until the vacancy is filled. When so authorized by the city council or the appropriate supervising board or commission, the city administrator may assume the duties of any department head of the city. 
(2)  The city administrator may set aside any action taken by any department head responsible to him and may supersede any such officer in any or all assigned functions, to the extent consistent with state law and the charter. 
(3)  The city administrator may direct any department or division or bureau thereof to perform the work of any other city department, division or bureau or the administrator may delegate to any officer or employee within such department, any duties other than those established for such division or bureau except in those instances where the department or activity does not report directly to the city administrator, in which cases prior authorization by the city council or governing commission or board, as appropriate, would be required. 
(Code 1968, § 2-14; Ord. No. 350, § 4, 7-7-80) 
Sec. 2-70. - Authorization to adopt administrative regulations. 
    The city administrator is authorized to adopt such administrative regulations in addition to, but not inconsistent with, the charter and this Code, as he shall deem necessary and proper to provide for the adequate functioning of all departments. Such regulations shall be subject to the approval of the mayor and the council and when so adopted and approved, shall comprise the administrative manual. 
(Code 1968, § 2-15; Ord. No. 350, § 5, 7-7-80) 
Sec. 2-71. - Approval of legal documents. 
    The city administrator shall approve as to substance all legal documents which are required to be signed by the mayor and clerk. 
(Code 1968, § 2-16; Ord. No. 350, § 6, 7-7-80) 
Sec. 2-72. - Authority in relation to employees; termination hearings. 
(a)  The city administrator shall have the authority to employ, assign, discipline, suspend and terminate all city employees except city officers appointed by the council. 
(b)  Opportunity for informal hearing prior to termination. Prior to termination of employment for cause, the city administrator shall give notice in writing to the employee of intent to terminate for the reasons set forth in the notice and shall provide an opportunity to the employee to respond to the reasons at an informal hearing to be held before a hearing panel consisting of the city administrator, the department head of the employee, the mayor and a member of the city council to be selected by the mayor. The findings of the hearing panel shall be stated in writing and delivered to the council for informational purposes and to the employee so terminated. 
(Code 1968, § 2-16.1; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 7-1-85) 
Sec. 2-73. - Title. 
    The city administrator shall also be known as and referred to as "city manager". 
(Ord. No. 576, § 1, 1-6-97) 
Secs. 2-74-2-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-86. - Duty to keep journal of council proceedings; reading, approval, signing. 
    The city clerk shall be the clerk of the council and shall keep the journal of council proceedings, each installment of which shall be read and approved at the next succeeding council meeting. The approval of the council shall be noted in the proceedings, with the date, and signed by the mayor and clerk. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 1, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-87. - Annual reports required. 
    The clerk shall submit an annual statement of the activities of his office for the previous year at the first meeting of the council in each new fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 1, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-20) 
Charter reference- Fiscal year defined, § 8.1. 
Sec. 2-88. - Custody of records. 
    The clerk shall have the care and custody of all city records not otherwise under the direction and care of other department heads. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 1, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-22) 
Sec. 2-89. - Appointment, duties of deputies. 
    The city clerk may, with the approval of the council, appoint such deputies as he deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 1, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-23) 
Sec. 2-90. - Additional duties. 
    The clerk shall perform such other duties as are prescribed by the city charter, the general laws of the state or by the council. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 1, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-24) 
Secs. 2-91-2-100. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-102. - Duties. 
    The city attorney shall be the legal adviser of the city council and all officials of the city with reference to matters pertaining to the city.

DIVISION 5. - ASSESSOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Appointment of assessor required, § 4.4. 

Sec. 2-116. - Duty to assess property, spread taxes. 
    The city assessor is charged with estimating the value of taxable real and personal property in the city, with making the assessment roll and with spreading upon the roll any and all taxes duly certified to him by order of the council, or by other proper authority. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 2, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-35) 
Charter reference- Preparation of assessment roll, § 9.1. 
Sec. 2-117. - Duty to make special assessments. 
    The assessor is charged with making any special assessment ordered by the council, in such manner and on such basis as the council may direct. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 2, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-36) 
Charter reference- Special assessments, § 9.5. 
Secs. 2-118-2-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - TREASURER[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Appointment of treasurer required, § 4.4. 

Sec. 2-131. - Charged with custody of funds. 
    The city treasurer is charged with the custody of all money of the city and all other public funds coming into his hands as city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 3, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-47) 
Sec. 2-132. - Duty to collect, receive, disburse funds. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, the treasurer shall collect, receive and, upon warrant issued by his office, disburse all public money of the city, and shall also receive and disburse all other public money coming into his hands as city treasurer, in pursuance of such regulations as may be prescribed by the authorities having lawful control over such funds. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 3, 7-6-31; Code 1968, § 2-48; Ord. No. 442, § 2, 9-11-89) 
Sec. 2-133. - Deposit of funds. 
    The treasurer shall make daily deposits of all public moneys received in his office in such bank or banks as may be selected by the council as the city depository, and shall cause a duplicate copy to be maintained as part of the account receivable records of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 2-49; Ord. No. 442, § 2, 9-11-89) 
Sec. 2-134. - Financial responsibilities. 
(1)  Under the direction of the city administrator or his designee, participates in the preparation of each annual budget proposal and general appropriations act for the ensuing year. 
(2)  Keep account of all funds collected by each administrative unit. 
(3)  Authorizes checks or warrants for the disbursement of funds from the city's treasury. 
(4)  Under the general direction of the city administrator, audits the financial records of each administrative unit to ensure compliance with the current fiscal year appropriation act. 
(5)  Establish and maintain a general accounting plan for the city government, which shall conform to any uniform system of accounting as required by law. 
(6)  Keep a separate account of each item within all budgetary centers for expenditure control of appropriations made by the council, for administrative units and other governmental units and agencies, to the extent and in the manner requested by the city administrator and required by law. 
(7)  Prescribe and supervise the keeping of detailed accounting records by administrative units of the city. 
(8)  Submit to the city council, through the city administrator, by the 15th working day of each month, a statement showing the balances at the close of the preceding month, in all funds and budget items, the amount of the city's known liabilities and budget items to which the same are to be charged, and all other information necessary to show the city's financial condition. 
(9)  Prepare and coordinate for the city administrator, within 60 days following the end of each fiscal year, a financial statement and report of the city's financial condition as of the end of the fiscal year. 
(10)  The city treasurer shall be the chief accounting official of the city and shall keep all budgetary accounts, reporting monthly through the city administrator to the city council on the financial condition of the city. 
(11)  The city treasurer shall submit an annual statement of the financial condition of the city by arranging for the conducting of and representation of the required annual audit. 
(12)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by charter, ordinance and resolutions of the council. 
(Code 1968, § 2-50; Ord. No. 442, § 3, 9-11-89; Ord. No. 572, § 1, 6-17-96; Ord. No. 747, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 2-135. - Appointment, duties of deputies. 
    The city treasurer may, with the approval of the council, appoint such deputies as he deems necessary. 
(Code 1968, § 2-51; Ord. No. 442, § 3, 9-11-89) 
Secs. 2-136-2-138. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 572, § 2, adopted June 17, 1996, repealed former §§ 2-136-2-138, relative to duties to make purchases, accounting and monthly reports and annual report, which derived from Code 1968, §§ 2-52-2-54 and Ord. No. 442, § 3, Sept 11, 1989. 
Sec. 2-139. - Duty to issue orders for payment.

Sec. 2-140. - Title. 
    The city treasurer shall also be known as and referred to as "city treasurer/collector." 
(Ord. No. 572, § 3, 6-17-96) 
Secs. 2-141-2-150. - Reserved.

DIVISION 9. - PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING 

Sec. 2-166. - Policies. 
    The following policies shall be in effect regarding the purchasing of and contracting for materials, supplies, capital outlay, or services necessary for maintenance, repair and operation of city facilities within the City of Saline. 
(Ord. No. 572, § 5, 6-17-96) 
Sec. 2-167. - Authority. 
    Authority granted to city administrator without further council action: 
(1)  The city administrator is hereby granted the authority to purchase and contract for materials, supplies, capital outlay, or services necessary for maintenance, repair and operation of city facilities under the following conditions: 
a.  The amount per order does not exceed $15,000.00. Repetitive orders of less than $15,000.00 shall not be used to circumvent this limitation. 
b.  Appropriate funds are available for this purchase. 
(2)  The city administrator is hereby granted the authority to approve contract change orders that do not exceed $15,000.00 or ten percent of the project budget, whichever is less, provided that appropriate funds are available to cover said change order. 
(Ord. No. 572, § 5, 6-17-96; Ord. No. 695, § 1, 7-10-06) 
Sec. 2-168. - Council approval required. 
    The approval of the city council is required under the following conditions notwithstanding the authority granted in section 2-167 above: 
(a)  The purchase of any bid over $15,000.00 which is not the low responsive bid. 
(b)  The purchase of an item as a single source if over $15,000.00. 
(c)  Purchases which continue for a term longer than the current annual budget if the multiyear total is over $15,000.00. 
(d)  Any other situation wherein the city treasurer, city administrator, city attorney, or internal auditor deems it appropriate to have formal action by city council. 
(Ord. No. 572, § 5, 6-17-96; Ord. No. 695, § 2, 7-10-06) 
Sec. 2-169. - Requirements of competition. 
(a)  Except for professional services, the following are requirements for competitive bidding, request for proposal or substantiation to the city administrator as a "sole source" procurement. Purchases in one budget year should not be broken into smaller parts to avoid the following procedures: 
(1)  Below $999.00 by good business practice. 
(2)  $1,000.00 to $4,999.00 on an informal competitive basis such as handwritten record of telephone calls to three sources, to be placed in file. 
(3)  $5,000.00 to $14,999.00 through written quotations sought from at least three sources. 
(4)  $15,000.00 or more through competitive bidding. 
(b)  A written record of completing the proper purchasing procedure should be kept for financial audit purposes with the purchase order, which will subsequently be connected with the resulting expenditures to fulfill invoices received. Evaluation will be made whether a responding vendor is responsible and responsive, as well as on price which must be closely competitive. A judgment will be made regarding the choice which will most benefit the city as a whole with all criteria taken into consideration. 
(c)  The city council may approve exceptions to the above competitive bidding requirements if it determines doing so is in the city's best interests. 
(Ord. No. 572, § 5, 6-17-96; Ord. No. 695, § 3, 7-10-06; Ord. No. 788 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 2-170. - Inclusion of local vendors. 
    The city wants to choose the "best bid" which is not necessarily the lowest bid. For this reason local vendors, recycled resources and local professional services may be allowed a small price advantage for small routine purchases. Obtaining goods and services locally may be better in terms of efficiency, flexibility of returning goods, speed of delivery on change orders, better communications, etc. 
    Local tradesmen should also be provided relevant bid notices or requests for proposals. However they must have a record of employment of appropriate levels of personnel and equipment which can fulfill the requirements with good workmanship, without an undue amount of subcontracting, in order to be judged responsible. In order to be judged responsive they must commit to meeting all of the requirements in a timely manner. Their price must be closely competitive. The chosen vendor will be the one judged to most benefit the city, with all criteria taken into consideration. 
(Ord. No. 572, § 5, 6-17-96) 
Sec. 2-171. - Emergency procedures. 
    The city administrator may, if requested by a department head, and/or deemed appropriate due to emergency situations that may affect the health, safety or welfare of the city, approve the purchase of necessary materials and supplies without the above requirements. However, such purchase action must be reported to the city council at its next regular meeting, where that purchase exceeds $5,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 572, § 5, 6-17-96) 
Secs. 2-172-2-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-176. - Enforcement of rules, regulations set by boards and commissions; penalty. 
(a)  All boards and commissions of the city which are authorized by ordinance to make rules and regulations pertaining to the use of the real and personal property under their jurisdiction shall have the authority to give notice to the public of such rules and regulations by whatever means are deemed by such boards and commissions to be necessary and reasonable to inform the public of such rules and regulations; provided, however, that no such rules and regulations shall become effective until they have received the approval of the city council by resolution duly adopted. 
(b)  All persons shall obey all rules and regulations referred to in subsection (a) in all cases where notice thereof has been given in such a manner that an ordinarily observant person would have been made aware of such rules and regulations. 
(c)  Any person who shall violate such rules and regulations, after being duly notified thereof as hereinabove provided, shall, upon conviction thereof, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the penalties therefor provided by law. 
(Code 1968, § 2-8; Ord. No. 293, §§ 1-3, 11-17-75) 
Secs. 2-177-2-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INDUSTRIAL AND BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-186. - Created; members. 
    There is hereby created in and for the city a commission for industrial and business development, consisting of nine members to be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. Such members shall, insofar as is practical, represent a cross section of the economic and geographic composition of the city, and shall be selected because of their interest in the development of commercial and industrial opportunities in the city, and shall include one member of the city council to be appointed annually with full voting rights. Of the remaining members first appointed, four shall be appointed to serve a term of one year and four for two years, and thereafter each member shall be appointed for a two-year term. Each member shall serve without pay and shall hold office until his successor has been appointed and qualified. The council shall annually appoint one member of the city staff to attend all meetings as a liaison officer without voting rights. The commission shall designate from its members a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. The city council may remove from office any members for cause. 
(Code 1968, § 2-71; Ord. No. 225, § 1, 8-23-71; Ord. No. 313, § 1, 5-17-77) 
Sec. 2-187. - Purpose; duties generally. 
    It shall be the purpose of the industrial and business development commission to foster and encourage industrial and commercial development programs designed to broaden and strengthen the economy of the city, and to provide specific leadership. In the following instances, among others, the commission shall: 
(1)  Encourage the location of new industrial and commercial enterprises within the city by appropriate legitimate methods. 
(2)  Support and assist the efforts of local industrial and commercial committees, labor organizations and other similar public and private agencies and corporations, individuals and partnerships to obtain new, and foster the expansion of existing industrial, and commercial facilities or enterprises. 
(3)  Investigate, assemble, develop and study or cause to have investigated, assembled, developed and studied, all pertinent information regarding the industrial opportunities and possibilities of the city and its economic resources and the particular divisions thereof, including raw materials and products that may be produced therefrom, power and water resources, transportation facilities and rates available, markets and the marketing limitations of the state and city, the availability of labor and those persons with technical and professional skills, the availability of industrial and commercial sites, the advantages of the city as a whole and the particular sections thereof as industrial locations, and such other fields of research and study as the commission and city council may deem necessary. 
(4)  Formulate and maintain coordinated plans for the economic and resource development of the city in order to promote the economic welfare of the people of the city. Such plans shall include description of the development objectives and a statement of recommended means for achieving such objectives. The plans shall be coordinated with the city, state, county or regional planning programs, and with national planning. 
(5)  Investigate, study and undertake ways and means to promote and develop markets for industrial products. 
(6)  Encourage the formation of local development committees throughout the city and make available to such committees, private groups, organizations, associations and agencies such facts, data and information as may be useful and desirable in their efforts to encourage the location of industries and commercial enterprise within the city and in other ways to cooperate with the commission in carrying out the purposes of this division. 
(7)  Provide advice and assistance to business and labor in the city and bring to the attention of the city administrator and city council by reports to be made at least annually, such significant problems as may be relieved by action of the city. 
(8)  Perform such other related acts as shall be, in the judgment of the city council, necessary and proper to carry out the objectives of this division. 
(Code 1968, § 2-72; Ord. No. 225, § 2, 8-23-71) 
Sec. 2-188. - Promotion of new economic enterprises. 
    The industrial and business development commission shall provide coordinated services to aid the city and local groups in the promotion of new economic enterprises and shall conduct such publicity and promotional activities as are desirable to stimulate all facets of the economy, and to this end shall: 
(1)  Collect and disseminate information regarding the advantages of locating and developing industrial and commercial enterprises in the city. 
(2)  Serve as the official city liaison agency between persons interested in locating new economic enterprises in the city and the city council. In this respect, the commission shall aid committees in the city in organizing for obtaining new business or expanding existing business. 
(3)  Encourage public and private agencies or bodies to publicize the facilities and attractions of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 2-73; Ord. No. 225, § 3, 8-23-71) 
Sec. 2-189. - Access to records, data, information of city departments, etc. 
    So far as may be practicable in the performance of its duties in connection with collecting and assembling of information, the industrial and business development commission shall make use of pertinent data as may be secured from the departments, boards, commissions, agencies and institutions of the city. The commission shall have access to all records, data, information and statistics of all departments, boards, commissions, agencies and institutions of the city except such records or information as are required by law to be kept confidential. 
(Code 1968, § 2-74; Ord. No. 225, § 4, 8-23-71) 
Secs. 2-190-2-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION 

Sec. 2-201. - Approval, adoption of application and related documents. 
    The application dated December 9, 1977, and articles of incorporation and bylaws for the economic development corporation of the city are hereby approved and adopted. 
(Code 1968, § 2-78; Ord. No. 326, § 1, 2-6-78) 
Sec. 2-202. - Authorization to incorporate.

(Code 1968, § 2-79; Ord. No. 326, § 1, 2-6-78) 
Secs. 2-203-2-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - HISTORIC DISTRICT ORDINANCE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 588, § 1, adopted Aug. 10, 1998, repealed the former Div. 4, §§ 2-216-2-230, and enacted a new Div. 4 as set out herein. The former Div. 4 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1968, §§ 2-80-2-94; Ord. No. 243, §§ 1-14, 2-19-73; Ord. No. 299, § 1, 4-5-76; Ord. No. 440, § 1, 7-24-89; Ord. No. 463, §§ 1, 2, 9-24-90; and Ord. No. 470, §§ 1, 2, 12-17-90. 

Sec. 2-216. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Alteration means work that changes the detail of a resource but does not change its basic size or shape. 
    Bureau means the bureau of history of the Michigan department of state. 
    Certificate of appropriateness means the written approval of a permit application for work that is appropriate and that does not adversely affect a resource. 
    Commission means the historic district commission created by the Saline City Council pursuant to this division. 
    Committee means a historic district study committee appointed by the Saline City Council pursuant to section 2-218 or section 2-229. 
    Demolition means the razing or destruction, whether entirely or in part, of a resource and includes, but is not limited to, demolition by neglect. 
    Demolition by neglect means neglect in maintaining, repairing, or securing a resource that results in deterioration of an exterior feature of the resource or the loss of structural integrity of the resource. 
    Denial means the written rejection of a permit application for work that is inappropriate and that adversely affects a resource. 
    Historic district means an area, or group of areas not necessarily having contiguous boundaries, that contains one resource or a group of resources that are related by history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, or culture. 
    Historic preservation means the identification, evaluation, establishment, and protection of resources significant in history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, or culture. 
    Historic resource means a publicly or privately owned building, structure, site, object, feature, or open space that is significant in the history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, or culture of this state or a community within this state, or of the United States. 
    Local unit means a county, city, village, or township. 
    Notice to proceed means the written permission to issue a permit for work that is inappropriate and that adversely affects a resource, pursuant to a finding under section 2-220(6). 
    Open space means undeveloped land, a naturally landscaped area, or a formal or man-made landscaped area that provides a connective link or a buffer between other resources. 
    Ordinary maintenance means keeping a resource unimpaired and in good condition through ongoing minor intervention, undertaken from time to time, in its exterior condition. Ordinary maintenance does not change the external appearance of the resource except through the elimination of the usual and expected effects of weathering. Ordinary maintenance does not constitute work for purposes of this division. 
    Proposed historic district means an area, or group of areas not necessarily having contiguous boundaries, that has delineated boundaries and that is under review by a committee or a standing committee for the purpose of making a recommendation as to whether it should be established as a historic district or added to an established historic district. 
    Repair means to restore a decayed or damaged resource to a good or sound condition by any process. A repair that changes the external appearance of a resource constitutes work for purposes of this division. 
    Resource means one or more publicly or privately owned historic or nonhistoric buildings, structures, sites, objects, features, or open spaces located within a historic district. 
    Standing committee means a permanent body established by the Saline City Council pursuant to section 2-229 to conduct the activities of a historic district study committee on a continuing basis. 
    Work means construction, addition, alteration, repair, moving, excavation, or demolition." 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-217. - Historic preservation as public purpose; purpose of ordinance. 
    Historic preservation is declared to be a public purpose and the city council may by ordinance regulate the construction, addition, alteration, repair, moving, excavation, and demolition of resources in historic districts within the limits of the city. The purpose of the ordinance shall be to do one or more of the following: 
(1)  Safeguard the heritage of the local unit by preserving one or more historic districts in the local unit that reflect elements of the unit's history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, or culture. 
(2)  Stabilize and improve property values in each district and the surrounding areas. 
(3)  Foster civic beauty. 
(4)  Strengthen the local economy. 
(5)  Promote the use of historic districts for the education, pleasure, and welfare of the citizens of the city and of the state. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-218. - Historic districts; establishment; study committee; duties; public hearing; notice; actions; availability of writings to public. 
(a)  A city may, by ordinance, establish one or more historic districts. The historic districts shall be administered by a commission established pursuant to section 2-219. Before establishing a historic district, the city council shall appoint a historic district study committee. The committee shall contain a majority of persons who have a clearly demonstrated interest in or knowledge of historic preservation, and shall contain representation from one or more duly organized local historic preservation organizations. The committee shall do all of the following: 
(1)  Conduct a photographic inventory of resources within each proposed historic district following procedures established or approved by the bureau. 
(2)  Conduct basic research of each proposed historic district and the historic resources located within that district. 
(3)  Determine the total number of historic and nonhistoric resources within a proposed historic district and the percentage of historic resources of that total. In evaluating the significance of historic resources, the committee shall be guided by the selection criteria for evaluation issued by the United States Secretary of the Interior for inclusion of resources in the national register of historic places, as setforth in 36 C.F.R. part 60, and criteria established or approved by the bureau, if any. 
(4)  Prepare a preliminary historic district study committee report that addresses at a minimum all of the following: 
a.  The charge of the committee. 
b.  The composition of the committee membership. 
c.  The historic district or districts studied. 
d.  The boundaries for each proposed historic district in writing and on maps. 
e.  The history of each proposed historic district. 
f.  The significance of each district as a whole, as well as a sufficient number of its individual resources to fully represent the variety of resources found within the district, relative to the evaluation criteria. 
g.  Transmit copies of the preliminary report for review and recommendations to the local planning body, to the bureau, to the state historical commission, and to the state historic preservation review board. 
h.  Make copies of the preliminary report available to the public pursuant to subsection (b), below. 
(b)  Not less than 60 calendar days after the transmittal of the preliminary report, the committee shall hold a public hearing in compliance with Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of 1976, as amended, being MCL 15.261-15.275. Public notice of the time, date, and place of the hearing shall be given in the manner required by Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of 1976, as amended. Written notice shall be mailed by first-class mail not less than 14 calendar days before the hearing to the owners of properties within the proposed historic district, as listed on the tax rolls of the city. 
(c)  After the date of the public hearing, the committee and the city council shall have not more than one year, unless otherwise authorized by the city council, to take the following actions: 
(1)  The committee shall prepare and submit a final report with its recommendations and the recommendations, if any, of the local planning body to the city council. If the recommendation is to establish a historic district or districts, the final report shall include a draft of a proposed ordinance or ordinances. 
(2)  After receiving a final report that recommends the establishment of a historic district or districts, the city council, at its discretion, may introduce and pass or reject an ordinance or ordinances. If the city passes an ordinance or ordinances establishing one or more historic districts, the city shall file a copy of that ordinance or those ordinances, including a legal description of the property or properties located within the historic district or districts, with the register of deeds. A city shall not pass an ordinance establishing a contiguous historic district less than 60 days after a majority of the property owners within the proposed historic district, as listed on the tax rolls of the city, have approved the establishment of the historic district pursuant to a written petition. 
(d)  A writing prepared, owned, used, in the possession of, or retained by a committee in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with Act No. 442 of the Public Acts of 1976, as amended, being sections 15.231 to 15.246 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-219. - Historic district commission; establishment; appointment, qualifications; terms of members; vacancy. 
    There is hereby created and established a commission to be called the historic district commission. Each member of the commission shall reside within the city. The membership of the historic district commission shall consist of seven members. A majority of the members shall have a clearly demonstrated interest in or knowledge of historic preservation. The members shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council. Initial members shall be appointed within six months after the adoption of this division. Members shall be appointed for three-year terms except the initial appointments of some of the members shall be for less than three years so that the initial appointments are staggered and that subsequent appointments do not recur at the same time. Members shall be eligible for reappointment. A vacancy on this commission shall be filled within 60 calendar days by appointment made by the appointing authority. An appointment shall be terminated by the appointing authority for three consecutive absences from duly scheduled meetings of the commission which have not been excused by a majority of the members of the commission. At lease one member of the commission shall be appointed from a list of citizens submitted by one or more duly organized local historical preservation organizations. The commission shall also include as a member, if available, a graduate of an accredited school of architecture who has two years of architectural experience or who is an architect registered in this state. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-220. - Permit requirement. 
(a)  A permit shall be obtained before undertaking any work described in subsection (d) below. The person, individual, partnership, firm, corporation, organization, institution, or agency of government proposing to do that work shall file an application for a permit with the inspector of buildings, the commission, or other duly delegated authority. If the inspector of buildings or other authority receives the application, the application shall be immediately referred together with all required supporting materials that make the application complete to the commission. A permit shall not be issued and proposed work shall not proceed until the commission has acted on the application by issuing a certificate of appropriateness or a notice to proceed as prescribed in this act. The city may charge a reasonable fee, as established by the city council from time to time, to process a permit application. 
(b)  An applicant aggrieved by a decision of the commission concerning a permit application may file an appeal with the state historic preservation review board of the state historical commission. A applicant aggrieved by the decision of the state historic preservation review board may then appeal the decision to the circuit court in Washtenaw County. 
(c)  In reviewing plans, the commission shall follow the U.S. Secretary of the Interior's standards for rehabilitation and guidelines for rehabilitating historic buildings, as set forth in 36 C.F.R. part 67. Design review standards and guidelines that address special design characteristics of historic districts administered by the commission may be followed if they are equivalent in guidance to the secretary of interior's standards and guidelines and are established or approved by the state agency authorized to give such approval. The commission shall also consider all of the following: 
(1)  The historic or architectural value and significance of the resource and its relationship to the historic value of the surrounding area. 
(2)  The relationship of any architectural features of the resource to the rest of the resource and to the surrounding area. 
(3)  The general compatibility of the design, arrangement, texture, and materials proposed to be used. 
(4)  Other factors, such as aesthetic value, that the commission finds relevant. 
(5)  Whether the applicant has certified in the application that the property where work will be undertaken has, or will have before the proposed project completion date, a fire alarm system or a smoke alarm complying with the requirements of the Stille-DeRossett-Hale Single State Construction Code Act, 1972 PA 230, as amended, MCL 125.1501 et seq. 
(d)  The commission shall not disapprove an application due to considerations not prescribed in subsection (c), above. The commission shall review and act only upon proposals for work involving: 
(1)  Exterior changes requiring a building permit. 
(2)  Exterior changes requiring a demolition permit, including both complete or partial demolition. 
(3)  Installation or removal of fences. 
(4)  Installation or removal of sheds, barns, garages, carriage houses, or other accessory buildings. 
(5)  Installation or removal of windows, window awnings, or window components (including window sashes and storm windows). 
(6)  Installation or removal of siding. 
(7)  Installation or removal of exterior doors and storm/screen doors. 
(8)  Installation or removal of roofing. 
(9)  Changes to the alignment, width, material or elevation of driveways. 
(10)  Landscaping proposals that result in more than a de minimis change in the contouring or elevations of a property, or that incorporate the use of paving and retaining walls. Review is not needed for the selection, placement or movement of plantings. 
(11)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as requiring commission review of activities constituting ordinary maintenance. 
(e)  If an application is for work that will adversely affect the exterior of a resource the commission considers valuable to the city, state, or nation, and the commission determines that the alteration or loss of that resource will adversely affect the public purpose of the city, state, or nation, the commission shall attempt to establish with the owner of the resource an economically feasible plan for preservation of the resource. 
(f)  Work within a historic district shall be permitted through the issuance of a notice to proceed by the commission if any of the following conditions prevail and if the proposed work can be demonstrated by a finding of the commission to be necessary to substantially improve or correct any of the following conditions: 
(1)  The resource constitutes a hazard to the safety of the public or to the structure's occupants. 
(2)  The resource is a deterrent to a major improvement program that will be of substantial benefit to the community and the applicant proposing the work has obtained all necessary planning and zoning approvals, financing, and environmental clearances. 
(3)  Retaining the resource will cause undue financial hardship to the owner when a governmental action, an act of God, or other events beyond the owner's control created the hardship, and all feasible alternatives to eliminate the financial hardship, which may include offering the resource for sale at its fair market value or moving the resource to a vacant site within the historic district, have been attempted and exhausted by the owner. 
(4)  Retaining the resource is not in the interest of the majority of the community. 
(g)  The business that the commission may perform shall be conducted at a public meeting of the commission held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act, 1976 PA 267, as amended, MCL 15.261 et seq., and public notice of the time, date, and place of the meeting shall also be given in the manner required under the act. A meeting agenda shall be part of the notice and shall include a listing of each permit application to be reviewed or considered by the commission. 
(h)  The commission shall keep a record of its resolutions, proceedings, and actions. A writing prepared, owned, used, in the possession of, or retained by the commission in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, as amended, MCL 15.231 et seq. 
(i)  The commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall adopt design review standards and guidelines for resource treatment to carry out its duties under this section. 
(j)  The commission may delegate the issuance of certificates of appropriateness for specified minor classes of work to its staff, to the inspector of buildings, or to another delegated authority. The commission shall provide to the delegated authority specific written standards for issuing certificates of appropriateness under this subsection. On at least a quarterly basis, the commission shall review the certificates of appropriateness, if any, issued for work by its staff, the inspector, or another authority to determine whether or not the delegated responsibilities should be continued. 
(k)  Upon a finding by a commission that a historic resource within a historic district or a proposed historic district subject to its review and approval is threatened with demolition by neglect, the commission may do either of the following: 
(1)  Require the owner of the resource to repair all conditions contributing to demolition by neglect. 
(2)  If the owner does not make repairs within a reasonable time, the commission or its agents may enter the property and make such repairs as are necessary to prevent demolition by neglect. The costs of the work shall be charged to the owner, and may be levied by the city as a special assessment against the property. The commission or its agents may enter the property for purposes of this section upon obtaining an order from the circuit court. 
(l)  When work has been done upon a resource without a permit, and the commission finds that the work does not qualify for a certificate of appropriateness, the commission may require an owner to restore the resource to the condition the resource was in before the inappropriate work or to modify the work so that it qualifies for a certificate of appropriateness. If the owner does not comply with the restoration or modification requirement within a reasonable time, the commission may seek an order from the circuit court to require the owner to restore the resource to its former condition or to modify the work so that it qualifies for a certificate of appropriateness. If the owner does not comply or cannot comply with the order of the court, the commission or its agents may enter the property and conduct work necessary to restore the resource to its former condition or modify the work so that it qualifies for a certificate of appropriateness in accordance with the court's order. The costs of the work shall be charged to the owner, and may be levied by the city as a special assessment against the property. When acting pursuant to an order of the circuit court, a commission or its agents may enter a property for purposes of this section. 
(Ord. No. 757 , § 1, 9-8-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 757 , § 1, adopted Sept. 8, 2014, amended § 2-220 in its entirety to read as herein set out. The former § 2-220 pertained to permit required; completed application; certificate of appropriateness or notice to proceed; issuance; permit fee; appeal to review board and circuit court; plan review standards, guidelines and considerations; scope of review; preservation plan; approval; conditions; public meeting; availability of writings to public; rules of procedure; approval of minor work; finding of demolition by neglect; restoration or modification of work done without permit, and derived from Ord. No. 588, § 1, adopted Aug. 10, 1998. 
Sec. 2-221. - Grants and gifts; benefit programs. 
    The city council may accept state or federal grants for historic preservation purposes, may participate in state and federal programs that benefit historic preservation, and may accept public or private gifts for historic preservation purposes. The city council may make the historic district commission, a standing committee, or other agency its duly appointed agent to accept and administer grants, gifts, and program responsibilities. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-222. - Historic resource; acquisition by the city council. 
    If all efforts by the historic district commission to preserve a resource fail, or if it is determined by the city council that public ownership is most suitable, the local legislative body, if considered to be in the public interest, may acquire the resource using public funds, public or private gifts, grants, or proceeds from the issuance of revenue bonds. The acquisition shall be based upon the recommendation of the commission or standing committee. The commission or standing committee is responsible for maintaining publicly owned resources using its own funds, if not specifically designated for other purposes, or public funds committed for that use by the city council. Upon recommendation of the commission or standing committee, the city may sell resources acquired under this section with protective easements included in the property transfer documents, if appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-223. - County historic district commission; coordination with township and city. 
    The jurisdiction of a county shall be the same as that provided in Act No. 183 of the Public Acts of 1943, as amended, being MCL 125.201-125.232, or as otherwise provided by contract entered into between the county and a city, village or township. If a county historic district commission is in existence, coordination between the county historic district commission and township and municipality historic district commissions shall be maintained. The overall historic preservation plans of cities, villages and townships shall be submitted to the county historic district commission for review, and county plans submitted to cities, villages, and townships having historic district commissions. Day-to-day activities of a commission shall not be reviewed unless the activities affect resources of importance to another commission. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-224. - Historic district commission; filings with delegated authority; duties of local public officials, employees, and bureau of history. 
(a)  The commission shall file certificates of appropriateness, notices to proceed, and denials of applications for permits with the inspector of buildings or other delegated authority. A permit shall not be issued until the commission has acted as prescribed by this act. If a permit application is denied, the decision shall be binding on the inspector or other authority. A denial shall be accompanied with a written explanation by the commission of the reasons for denial and, if appropriate, a notice that an application may be resubmitted for commission review when suggested changes have been made. The denial shall also include notification of the applicant's rights of appeal to the state historic preservation review board and to the circuit court. The failure of the commission to act within 60 calendar days after the date a complete application is filed with the commission, unless an extension is agreed upon in writing by the applicant and the commission, shall be considered to constitute approval. 
(b)  Local public officials and employees shall provide information and records to committees, commissions, and standing committees, and shall meet with those bodies upon request to assist with their activities. 
(c)  The bureau shall cooperate with and assist local units, committees, commissions, and standing committees in carrying out the purposes of this act and may establish or approve standards, guidelines, and procedures that encourage uniform administration of this act in this state but that are not legally binding on any individual or other legal entity. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-225. - Construction of act. 
    Nothing in this act shall be construed to prevent ordinary maintenance or repair of a resource within a historic district, or to prevent work on any resource under a permit issued by the inspector of buildings or other duly delegated authority before the ordinance was enacted. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-226. - Appeal of decisions. 
    Any citizen or duly organized historic preservation organization in the city, as well as resource property owners, jointly or severally aggrieved by a decision of the historic district commission may appeal the decision to the circuit court, except that a permit applicant aggrieved by a decision rendered under section 2-220(a) may not appeal to the court without first exhausting the right to appeal to the state historic preservation review board under section 2-220(b). 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-227. - Effect of ordinance as to existing legislation and historical commission. 
    This division shall not affect the membership or prior actions of the existing historic district commission, except to conform its membership, structure, and actions, to the provisions of Michigan Local Historic Districts Act, Act 169 of 1970, as amended by Act 230 of 1986 and Act 96 of 1992. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-228. - Powers and duties of historic district commission. 
(a)  The city may prescribe powers and duties of the historic district commission, in addition to those prescribed in Michigan Local Historic District Act, as amended, that foster historic preservation activities, projects, and programs in the city. The intent of the Saline Historic District Commission (HDC) in establishing local historic districts is to preserve the unique character of each district as an integral part of the Saline community. The goal of the HDC's design review is to retain the historic integrity of the resource while allowing for the owner's individuality and creativity. The design guidelines adopt the U.S. Secretary of the Interior Standards for Rehabilitation and Guidelines for Rehabilitating Historic Structures, and are meant to aid the property owner in making educated decisions about historic resources. 
(b)  It is not the intent of the historic district commission to be overly restrictive or burdensome. The process of review is one that aims to assist the property owner in the stewardship of historic resources. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98; Ord. No. 757 , § 1, 9-8-14) 
Sec. 2-229. - Establishing, modifying, or eliminating historic districts; study committee; considerations; review of applications within proposed historic district; emergency moratorium. 
(a)  The city may at any time establish by ordinance additional historic districts, including proposed districts previously considered and rejected, may modify boundaries of an existing historic district, or may eliminate an existing historic district. Before establishing, modifying, or eliminating a historic district, a historic district study committee appointed by the city council shall, except as provided in subsection (b), below, comply with the procedures set forth in section 2-218 and shall consider any previously written committee reports pertinent to the proposed action. To conduct these activities, the city may retain the initial committee, establish a standing committee, or establish a committee to consider only specific proposed districts and then be dissolved. 
(b)  If considering elimination of a historic district, a committee shall follow the procedures set forth in section 2-218 for issuing a preliminary report, holding a public hearing, and issuing a final report but with the intent of showing one or more of the following: 
(1)  The historic district has lost those physical characteristics that enabled establishment of the district. 
(2)  The historic district was not significant in the way previously defined. 
(3)  The historic district was established pursuant to defective procedures. 
(c)  Upon receipt of substantial evidence showing the presence of historic, architectural, archaeological, engineering, or cultural significance of a proposed historic district, the city council may, at its discretion, adopt a resolution requiring that all applications for permits within the proposed historic district be referred to the commission as prescribed in sections 2-220 and 2-224. The commission shall review permit applications with the same powers that would apply if the proposed historic district was an established historic district. The review may continue in the proposed historic district for not more than one year, or until such time as the city approves or rejects the establishment of the historic district by ordinance, whichever occurs first. 
(d)  If the city council determines that pending work will cause irreparable harm to resources located within an established historic district or a proposed historic district, the city council may by resolution declare an emergency moratorium of all such work for a period not to exceed six months. The city council may extend the emergency moratorium for an additional period not to exceed six months upon finding that the threat of irreparable harm to resources is still present. Any pending permit application concerning a resource subject to an emergency moratorium may be summarily denied. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 2-230. - Violation; fine; payment of costs. 
(a)  A person, individual, partnership, firm, corporation, organization, institution, or agency of government that violates this division is responsible for a civil violation and may be fined not more than $500.00 for each violation. 
(b)  A person, individual, partnership, firm, corporation, organization, institution, or agency of government that violates this division may be ordered by the court to pay the costs to restore or replicate a resource unlawfully constructed, added to, altered, repaired, moved, excavated, or demolished. 
Secs. 2-231-2-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ENVIRONMENTAL COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-241. - Established. 
    There is hereby created an environmental commission which shall be composed of seven members appointed annually by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. The commission shall meet at least once annually and other times as necessary. Minutes of the proceedings shall be kept and distributed to appropriate city staff. Commission meetings shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, and shall be open to the public in accordance with the provisions of the state open meetings act. 
(Code 1968, § 2-100; Ord. No. 473, § 1, 2-4-91; Ord. No. 614, § 1, 2-22-99) 
Sec. 2-242. - Duties. 
    The environmental commission shall review all matters of environmental importance to the city such as site plans, ordinances and other matters referred to it by the council, and shall make recommendations thereon to the city council. The commission shall also be charged with providing environmental information to the city council and shall investigate solutions to environmental problems and report thereon to the city council. 
(Code 1968, § 2-101; Ord. No. 473, § 1, 2-4-91) 
Sec. 2-243. - Council appropriations. 
    The council shall make the necessary appropriations annually to provide suitable quarters, facilities, equipment and personnel to carry out the work of the environmental commission. 
(Code 1968, § 2-102; Ord. No. 473, § 1, 2-4-91) 
Sec. 2-244. - Termination. 
    This division is made in the interest of public health and welfare and is designed to serve the public convenience and shall continue in force and effect until repealed. The effectiveness of this division shall be annually reviewed and evaluated by the city council which shall annually make a determination to repeal this division or to continue it in full force and effect. 
(Code 1968, § 2-103; Ord. No. 473, § 1, 2-4-91) 
Secs. 2-245-2-255. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SPECIAL PROJECTS COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 536, § 1, adopted May 2, 1994, repealed former Div. 6, §§ 2-256-2-260, relative to the urban design commission, and enacted a new Div. 6 to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Div. 6 derived from Code 1968, §§ 2-108-2-112; Ord. No. 317, § 1, adopted Aug. 1, 1977; Ord. No. 328, § 1, adopted Feb. 6, 1976; and Ord. No. 480, § 1, adopted April 15, 1991. 

Sec. 2-256. - Established. 
    There is hereby created a special projects commission which shall be composed of nine members to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council and shall include two members of the historic district commission, two members of the parks and beautification commission, two members of the economic development units (EDC, EDTF, LDFA, or TIFA), one member of the environmental commission, and two of which shall be the mayor and the member of council selected by it to serve on the planning commission, ex officio, with full voting rights. The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, shall also appoint one member of the city staff to attend commission meetings as a liaison without voting rights. The commission shall meet a minimum of two times a year and other times as necessary. Minutes of the proceedings shall be kept and distributed to appropriate city staff. Commission meetings shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order. 
(Ord. No. 536, § 1, 5-2-94; Ord. No. 655, § 1, 5-6-02) 
Sec. 2-257. - Areas of special concern. 
    The special projects commission shall recommend to the city council designation of "Areas of Special Concern" (ASC) which shall include those areas of open space and special areas of concern, which have special architectural, historical or aesthetic interest or potential, the character of which is desirable to maintain and enhance. The purpose of this designation shall be to call the attention to public sectors to their existence and importance. The special projects commission will assist in the coordination of plans, efforts and projects that the various city commissions are engaged in to insure a unity of purpose and an economy of effort. As needed the special projects commission will meet to review items of mutual concern at the direction of the mayor and city council and assist in the development of projects that involve multiple commissions. 
(Ord. No. 536, § 1, 5-2-94) 
Sec. 2-258. - Effect of designation as ASC. 
    Upon designation of an "Area of Special Concern" by the city council, the following rules and regulations shall become effective: 
(1)  All departments and commissions of the City of Saline must acknowledge the designation of ASC. No public plans, contracts or improvement work in the "Areas of Special Concern" shall commence without prior consultation with the special projects commission, except for emergency city services. 
(2)  All city budget requests affecting the character of ASC areas shall be submitted for review by the special projects commission. In formulating both annual and capital improvement budgets, all departments shall consider the impact of budget requests on designated "Areas of Special Concern." Technical and design advice shall be provided by the special projects commission. 
(3)  All public maintenance work shall conform with plans and policies approved by special projects commission in designated "Areas of Special Concern," subject to the adoption of such plans and policies by the city council. 
(4)  All master plan revisions shall contain references to designated "Areas of Special Concern" and the policies adopted by the special projects commission. 
(Ord. No. 536, § 1, 5-2-94) 
Sec. 2-259. - Coordination of city commissions. 
    The special projects commission may obtain from all city commissions a written description of the annual plans of each commission for review and discussion for the purpose of coordinating the activities of all city commissions. Upon completion of such review and discussion, the special projects commission shall prepare and deliver to the city council a written report of its findings and recommendations with a copy of such report to all city commissions. 
(Ord. No. 536, § 1, 5-2-94; Ord. No. 655, § 2, 5-6-02) 
Sec. 2-260. - Review of tax abatement applications. 
    The special projects commission shall review all tax abatement applications and make recommendations to the city council for action thereon. The special projects commission chairperson (or other officially designated reviewer) shall promptly review the analysis by city staff along with the complete application for tax abatement, whereupon the chairperson (or designated reviewer) shall either sign a recommendation for full approval of the requested tax abatement or call a meeting of the special projects commission to further discuss the request. 
(Ord. No. 536, § 1, 5-2-94; Ord. No. 655, § 3, 5-6-02) 
Sec. 2-261. - Work on special projects. 
    The special projects commission shall work on all other special projects assigned to it by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 536, § 1, 5-2-94) 
Sec. 2-262. - Council appropriations. 
    The council shall make the necessary appropriations annually to provide suitable quarters, facilities, equipment and personnel to carry out the work of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 536, § 1, 5-2-94) 
Sec. 2-263. - Termination. 
    This ordinance is made in the interest of public health and welfare and is designed to serve the public convenience and shall continue in force and effect until repealed The effectiveness of this ordinance shall be annually reviewed and evaluated by the city council which shall annually make a determination to repeal this ordinance or to continue it in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 536, § 1, 5-2-94) 
Sec. 2-264. - Severability. 
    If any phrase, clause, sentence or section of this ordinance should be declared illegal by any court of competent jurisdiction, this ordinance shall be deemed to have been adopted without such illegal phrase, clause, sentence or section and shall continue in full force and effect without such illegal portion. 
(Ord. No. 536, § 1, 5-2-94) 
Secs. 2-265-2-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - LOCAL OFFICERS COMPENSATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-271. - Created; membership. 
    A local officers compensation commission is created which shall determine the salaries of each local elected official. The commission shall consist of five members. The members shall be registered electors of the city, appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by a majority of the members elected and serving in the city council. The terms of office shall be five years, except that of the members first appointed, one each shall be appointed for terms of one, two, three, four and five years. The first members shall be appointed within 30 days after the effective date of Ordinance No. 468. Members other than the first members shall be appointed before October 1 of the year of appointment. Vacancies shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term. A member or employee of the legislative, judicial or executive branch of government or a member of the immediate family of a member or employee of the legislative, judicial or executive branch of government shall not be a member of the commission. 
(Code 1968, § 2-121; Ord. No. 468, § 1, 11-19-90) 
Sec. 2-272. - Duties and procedures. 
    The local officers compensation commission shall determine the salary of each local elected official. The determination shall be the salary unless the city council, by resolution adopted by two-thirds of the members elected to and serving on the council, rejects it. The determination of the commission shall be effective 30 days following its filing with the city clerk unless rejected by the council. If the determination is rejected, the existing salary shall prevail. The expense allowance or reimbursement paid to elected officials in addition to salary shall be for expenses incurred in the course of city business and accounted for to the city. 
(Code 1968, § 2-122; Ord. No. 468, § 2, 11-19-90) 
Sec. 2-273. - Meetings; quorum; organization; compensation. 
    The local officers compensation commission shall meet for not more than 15 session days in each odd-numbered year and shall make its determination within 45 calendar days after its first meeting. A majority of the members of the commission constitutes a quorum for conducting the business of the commission. The commission shall not take action or make a determination without a concurrence of a majority of the members appointed and serving on the commission. The commission shall elect a chairperson from among its members. As used in this section, "session day" means a calendar day on which the commission meets and a quorum is present. The members of the commission shall not receive compensation, but shall be entitled to actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of official duties. 
(Code 1968, § 2-123; Ord. No. 468, § 3, 11-19-90) 
Sec. 2-274. - Open meetings; notice. 
    The business which the local officers compensation commission may perform shall be conducted at a public meeting of the commission held in compliance with Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1976 (MCL 15.261 et seq.), as amended. Public notice of the time, date, and place of the meeting of the commission shall be given in the manner required by Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1976 (MCL 15.261 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1968, § 2-124; Ord. No. 468, § 4, 11-19-90) 
Sec. 2-275. - Records. 
    A writing prepared, owned, used, in the possession of, or retained by the local officers compensation commission in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with Act No. 442 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1976 (MCL 15.231 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1968, § 2-125; Ord. No. 468, § 5, 11-19-90) 
Secs. 2-276-2-290. - Reserved.
