ARTICLE VIII. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 803 , § 1, adopted Apr. 5, 2018, set out provisions intended for use as Art. VIII, §§ 18-2-18-8. Inasmuch as said sections already exist, said provisions have been redesignated as Art. VIII, §§ 18-161-18-168, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 18-161. - Dangerous building and structures ordinance. 
    This article is specifically authorized by the housing law, 1917 PA 167, as amended, and shall be known and cited as the City of Saline Dangerous Buildings Ordinance. 
( Ord. No. 803 , § 1, 4-5-18) 
Sec. 18-162. - Dangerous building unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent, lessee or party in interest to keep or maintain any building or part thereof which is a dangerous building or structure as defined in this article. 
( Ord. No. 803 , § 1, 4-5-18) 
Sec. 18-163. - Dangerous buildings defined. 
    As used in this article, the term "dangerous building" means any building or structure, residential or otherwise, which has any of the following defects or is in any of the following conditions: 
(1)  A door, aisle, passageway, stairway, or other means of exit does not conform to the requirements of the city's fire code. 
(2)  A portion of the building or structure is damaged by fire, wind, flood, deterioration, neglect, abandonment, vandalism, or other cause so that the structural strength or stability of the building or structure is significantly impaired and the structure does not meet the minimum requirements of the housing law or the Michigan Building Code for a new building or structure, purpose, or location. 
(3)  A part of the building or structure is likely to fall, become detached or dislodged, or collapse and injure persons or damage property. 
(4)  A portion of the building or structure has settled to an extent that walls or other structural portions of the building or structure have materially less resistance to wind than is required in the case of new construction by the housing law or the Michigan Building Code. 
(5)  The building or structure, or a part of the building or structure, because of dilapidation, deterioration, decay, faulty construction, the removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the support, or for other reason, is likely to partially or completely collapse, or some portion of the foundation or underpinning of the building or structure is likely to fall or give way. 
(6)  The building, structure, or a part of the building or structure is manifestly unsafe for the purpose for which it is used. 
(7)  The building or structure is damaged by fire, wind, or flood, is dilapidated or deteriorated and becomes an attractive nuisance to children who might play in the building or structure to their danger, becomes a harbor for vagrants, criminals, or immoral persons, or enables persons to resort to the building or structure for committing a nuisance or an unlawful act. 
(8)  A building or structure used or intended to be used for dwelling purposes, including the adjoining grounds, because of dilapidation, decay, damage, faulty construction or arrangement, or for other reason, is unsanitary or unfit for human habitation, is in a condition likely to cause sickness or disease, or is likely to injure the health, safety, or general welfare of people living in the dwelling. 
(9)  A building or structure is vacant, dilapidated, and open at door or window, leaving the interior of the building exposed to the elements or accessible to entrance by trespassers. 
(10)  An unfinished building or structure for which no certificate of occupancy has been issued and for which a building permit, site plan approval, or other zoning approval: (1) has been expired for at least six months; or (2) was the subject of an extension request denied by the planning commission or building official. 
( Ord. No. 803 , § 1, 4-5-18) 
Sec. 18-164. - Notice of dangerous building. 
(a)  The city building official may issue a notice pursuant to this section upon finding that a building or structure is a dangerous building. The notice shall be served on the owner, agent, or lessee registered with the city. If an owner, agent, or lessee is not registered with the city, the notice shall be served on each owner of or party in interest in the building or structure in whose name the property appears on the last local tax assessment records. 
(b)  The notice shall specify the time and place of a hearing on whether the building or structure is a dangerous building. The person to whom the notice is directed shall have the opportunity to show cause at the hearing why the hearing officer should not order the building or structure to be demolished, otherwise made safe, or properly maintained. 
(c)  The hearing officer shall be appointed by the mayor to serve at his or her pleasure. The hearing officer shall be a person who has expertise in housing matters including, but not limited to, an engineer, architect, building contractor, building inspector, or member of a community housing organization. An employee of the city shall not be appointed as hearing officer. The city shall file a copy of the notice that the building or structure is a dangerous building with the hearing officer. 
(d)  The notice shall be in writing and shall be served upon the person to whom the notice is directed either personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the owner or party in interest at the address shown on the tax records. If a notice is served on a person by certified mail, a copy of the notice shall also be posted upon a conspicuous part of the building or structure. The notice shall be served upon the owner or party in interest at least ten days before the date of the hearing included in the notice. 
( Ord. No. 803 , § 1, 4-5-18) 
Sec. 18-165. - Hearings and other proceedings. 
(a)  At the hearing, the hearing officer shall take testimony of the city, the owner of the property, and any interested party. Not more than five days after completion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall render a decision either closing the proceedings or ordering the building or structure demolished, otherwise made safe, or properly maintained. 
(b)  If the hearing officer determines that the building or structure should be demolished, otherwise made safe, or properly maintained, the hearing officer shall enter an order that specifies what action the owner, agent, or lessee shall take and sets a date by which the owner, agent, or lessee shall comply with the order. If the building is a dangerous building under the provisions of this article, the order may require the owner or agent, to bring and maintain the exterior of the building and adjoining grounds into compliance including, but not limited to, the maintenance of lawns, trees, and shrubs. 
(c)  If the owner, agent, or lessee fails to appear or neglects or refuses to comply with the order issued under subsection (b), the hearing officer shall file a report of the findings and a copy of the order with the city's construction board of appeals not more than five days after the date for compliance set in the order and request that necessary action be taken to enforce the order. A copy of the findings and order of the hearing officer shall be served on the owner, agent, or lessee in the manner prescribed in section 18-164. 
(d)  The construction board of appeals shall set a date not less than 30 days after the hearing prescribed in subsection (a) for an appellate hearing on the findings and order of the hearing officer. The construction board of appeals shall give notice to the owner, agent, or lessee in the manner prescribed in section 18-164 of the time and place of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner, agent, or lessee shall be given the opportunity to show cause why the order should not be enforced. The construction board of appeals shall either approve, disapprove, or modify the order. If the construction board of appeals approves or modifies the order, the city shall take all necessary action to enforce the order. If the order is approved or modified, the owner, agent, or lessee shall comply with the order within 60 days after the date of the hearing under this subsection. For an order of demolition, if the construction board of appeals of the city determines that the building or structure has been substantially destroyed by fire, wind, flood, deterioration, neglect, abandonment, vandalism, or other cause, and the cost of repair of the building or structure will be greater than the state equalized value of the building or structure, the owner, agent, or lessee shall comply with the order of demolition within 21 days after the date of the hearing under this subsection. If the estimated cost of repair exceeds the state equalized value of the building or structure to be repaired, a rebuttable presumption that the building or structure requires expedited demolition exists. 
(e)  The cost of demolition includes, but is not limited to, fees paid to hearing officers, costs of title searches or commitments used to determine the parties in interest, recording fees for notices and liens filed with the county register of deeds, demolition and dumping charges, court reporter attendance fees, and costs of the collection of the charges authorized under this article. The cost of the demolition, of making the building safe, or of maintaining the exterior of the building or structure or grounds adjoining the building or structure incurred by the city to bring the property into conformance with this article shall be reimbursed to the city by the owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears. 
(f)  The owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears upon the last local tax assessment records shall be notified by the assessor of the amount of the cost of the demolition, of making the building safe, or of maintaining the exterior of the building or structure or grounds adjoining the building or structure by first class mail at the address shown on the records. If the owner or party in interest fails to pay the cost within 30 days after mailing by the assessor of the notice of the amount of the cost, the city shall have a lien for the cost incurred by the city to bring the property into conformance with this article. The lien shall not take effect until notice of the lien has been filed or recorded as provided by law. A lien provided for in this subsection does not have priority over previously filed or recorded liens and encumbrances. The lien for the cost shall be collected and treated in the same manner as provided for property tax liens under the General Property Tax Act, 1893 PA 206, as amended. 
(g)  In addition to the other remedies provided under this article, the city may bring an action against the owner of a dangerous building or structure for the full cost of demolition, of making the building safe, or of maintaining the exterior or grounds adjoining a dangerous building or structure. The city shall have a lien on the property for the amount of a judgment obtained under this subsection. The lien provided for in this subsection shall not take effect until notice of the lien is filed or recorded as provided by law. The lien does not have priority over prior filed or recorded liens and encumbrances. 
( Ord. No. 803 , § 1, 4-5-18) 
Sec. 18-166. - Enforcement of judgment against other assets. 
(a)  A judgment in an action brought pursuant to section 18-165(g) may be enforced against assets of the owner other than the building or structure. 
(b)  The city shall have a lien for the amount of a judgment obtained pursuant to section 18-165(g) against the owner's interest in all real property located in this state that is owned in whole or in part by the owner of the building or structure against whom the judgment is obtained. A lien provided for in this section does not take effect until notice of the lien is filed or recorded as provided by law, and the lien does not have priority over prior filed or recorded liens or encumbrances. 
( Ord. No. 803 , § 1, 4-5-18) 
Sec. 18-167. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person who violates any provision of this dangerous building ordinance shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(b)  A person who fails or refuses to comply with an order approved or modified by the construction board of appeals under section 18-165 within the time prescribed by that section is guilty of misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 120 days or a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or both. 
( Ord. No. 803 , § 1, 4-5-18) 
Sec. 18-168. - Appeal of circuit court. 
    An owner or party in interest aggrieved by any final decision of the construction board of appeals may appeal the decision or order to the Washtenaw County Circuit Court by filing an appeal within 20 days from the date of such decision. 
( Ord. No. 803 , § 1, 4-5-18) 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLICITORS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 735, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2011, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 22-26-22-42, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to peddlers, solicitors and transient traders and derived from Ord. No. 107, §§ 1-7, adopted Sept. 20, 1939; Ord. No. 160, §§ 1-12, adopted Apr. 16, 1962; Res. of 160, adopted May 24, 1962; Code 1968, §§ 13-1-13-33. 

Sec. 22-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms shall be defined for the purposes of this article. 
    Person means an individual, organization, group, club, association, partnership, corporation, trust, business entity, or any combination of the above. 
    Solicit means the act of offering or attempting to offer wares, merchandise, services, items of personal property, or real property, either for immediate or future delivery; or the act of seeking or attempting to seek contributions of money or services, for charitable or commercial purposes. 
    Solicitor means a person, including but is not limited to canvasser, peddler, or hawker, who solicits when traveling either by foot, motorized vehicle or other means of conveyance, from place to place, house to house, or street to street. "Solicitor" does not include those who deliver or pick up goods on an established route at the request of the homeowners/resident. 
    Transient merchant as used in this section shall be construed to mean a person who occupies any space within the city for a period of 30 days or less for the purpose of conducting business or soliciting. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11; Ord. No. 739, § 1, 5-21-12) 
Sec. 22-27. - Exempt persons. 
    The following persons shall be exempt from the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Persons engaged in the distribution of newspapers. 
(2)  Any person associated with a public or private school, or youth activity such as, but not limited to, scouts, church groups, or athletic leagues located in the Saline Area School District. 
(3)  Persons engaged in noncommercial or religious canvassing. 
(4)  Persons who are attempting to speak with resident(s) and who are engaged in the distribution of signed or unsigned hand-bills, political or otherwise. 
(5)  Children conducting a neighborhood lemonade stand or similar type with parent's approval on their own property. 
(6)  Farmers or others selling homegrown produce, crafts, or other merchandise under special permission within a city event/market specially designated and located for that general purpose. 
(7)  The downtown merchants association, chamber of commerce, Saline Historic Downtown Alliance, Saline Historical Society, local service organizations or vendors who have been invited to participate in community events which have been approved by city council. 
(8)  Persons with a seasonal sale permit issued under [Appendix A] section 5.12 of the city Code. 
(9)  A person or organization exempted by state or federal law. 
(10)  Person validly operating a mobile food vending unit in accordance with article IV, chapter 22, of the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11; Ord. No. 798 , § 1, 5-7-18) 
Sec. 22-28. - License required; transfers. 
    No person other than those exempted in section 22-27, shall be a solicitor or transient merchant in the City of Saline without first obtaining a license from the city clerk. Licenses shall expire on the date specified on the license issued by the city clerk, but in no event shall a license be issued for a period exceeding one year. No license shall be transferred. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 22-29. - Fees. 
    The fees which shall be charged by the city clerk for a license under this article shall be established by resolution of the city council and published in the current copy of the City of Saline's Fee Book. The application fee shall be paid upon submittal of the application and the license fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of the license. All fees once submitted are non-refundable. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 22-30. - Application requirements. 
    Application for a license shall be made at the office of the city clerk on forms provided. In the event the application is made by an organization, group, association, partnership, corporation, trust, business entity, or any combination of the above, each individual soliciting/conducting business under the license applied for shall submit their individual information on the application forms provided. The following items must be attached, if applicable. The application process typically requires one week for review and approval. 
(1)  Copy of the Michigan Sales Tax License, or exemption certificate. 
(2)  Copy of government issued identification with photograph. 
(3)  Written consent of the legal owner of the property showing approval for this use of the property. 
(4)  Site plan/sketch indicating the layout of proposed activity that will take place on the property if at a fixed location. A zoning review will be conducted by the building/zoning department for compliance with local zoning requirements. 
(5)  Approval from Washtenaw County Health Department. 
(6)  A current copy of the non-profit 501(c) 3 status. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 22-31. - License refusal; appeal. 
    Upon review and investigation of the application and the information contained therein, the city clerk may refuse to issue the license for any one or more of the following reasons; 
(1)  The applicant has failed to previously comply with the provisions and requirements of the article. 
(2)  The applicant falsified information on the application or has not fully completed the application or it is illegible. 
(3)  The applicant has been convicted of a crime or a municipal civil infraction related to the activities covered by this article. 
(4)  The location, time, or method of solicitation will block or congest streets or sidewalks, or will impede the free flow of pedestrian or automobile traffic, or will otherwise endanger the health, safety, and/or welfare of the public. 
(5)  Or for any of the following reasons: 
a.  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license or in the operation of a business; 
b.  Any violation amounting to a felony, or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
c.  Conducting a business in an unlawful manner or in such manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, morals, safety, or welfare of the public; 
d.  The failure or inability of an applicant to meet and satisfy the requirements and provisions of this article. 
    Any business or individual whose license has been refused or denied shall have the right to petition the city council, in writing, for an appeal. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 22-32. - License revocation; appeal. 
    Any license issued by the city clerk may be suspended or revoked by the city clerk upon the clerk's findings based upon competent, material and substantial evidence of any of the following causes; 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for license or in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise. 
(2)  Any violation of a Saline ordinance, state, or federal law. 
(3)  Conviction by the licensee of any felony. 
(4)  Conducting the business in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute breach of the peace. 
    Notice of the revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds for the revocation. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at the address provided in the application. Any licensee whose license has been revoked as herein provided shall have the right to appeal the revocation to the city council as provided in section 22-32. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 22-33. - Prohibited activities. 
    The following acts or activities shall be prohibited: 
(1)  Fixed stands: No solicitor shall remain in one place upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public place unless the solicitor has obtained approval from the city council for use of public way. 
(2)  Prohibited areas: No solicitor shall obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk, or driveway. 
(3)  Entry upon property expressly requesting no solicitation: No solicitor shall enter a place within the city after having been expressly notified by an occupant or by a posted sign that no solicitation is desired and/or other language specifically conveying that message. 
(4)  Harassment or creation of nuisance: No solicitor shall threaten or harass any person in the city in the course of a solicitation or in any way engage in any conduct, which creates or would tend to create a nuisance. 
(5)  Loud sound or noise: No shouting, calling wares, using a public address system, horn, bells or other noisemaking device to call attention to the licensee's business. Exception: Neighborhood ice cream truck playing tunes at a reasonable sound level. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 22-34. - Hours of operation. 
    Door-to-door residential soliciting is only allowed within the city between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. No door-to-door soliciting on Sunday or nationally recognized holidays. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11; Ord. No. 739, § 2, 5-21-12) 
Sec. 22-35. - Duty to exhibit license. 
    All licensed solicitors and/or transient merchants are required to exhibit their city issued solicitor or transient merchant identification while soliciting. No person shall permit another person to use or employ a license issued to him/her by the city. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 22-36. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of any police or code enforcement officer of the city to enforce the provisions of this article. All complaints received or citations issued for violation of this article shall be reported to the city clerks office and the clerk shall maintain a record thereof. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 22-37. - Signs. 
    Any signs used by solicitors or transient merchants shall comply with the city's sign ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Secs. 22-38-22-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 22-50. - Massage establishments. 
(a)  License required. No person, firm, partnership, corporation or entity shall operate a massage establishment without first obtaining a license to do so from the city. 
(b)  Massage establishment defined. For purposes of this section, the term "massage establishment" shall mean a business establishment in which practice of massage therapy, as defined in the Michigan Public Health Code, 368 PA 1978, as amended, is one of the primary services provided. The following establishments shall not be considered massage establishments: 
(1)  Hospitals, doctors' offices, nursing homes, and other facilities in which massages are performed incidental to the provision of healthcare services. 
(2)  Establishments in which barbers or beauticians perform massages incidental to the provision of hairstyling or other similar services. 
(c)  Licensing of massage establishments. 
(1)  An application to operate a massage establishment shall be made to the city clerk. The application shall be made on a form provided by the city clerk and signed under oath stating that the information contained in the application is true and accurate. Any false statement set forth in an application shall be a violation of this article. The license fee (set by the city council) must be paid at the time of application and the license shall not be processed until the following information has been supplied to the city clerk: 
a.  The full name, residential address, business address and telephone numbers of each applicant, owner and each manager. If the applicant or owner is a corporation, the names and residential addresses of each of the officers and directors of the corporation and each shareholder owning ten percent interest or more in the corporation, either directly or beneficially, shall also be given. If the applicant or owner is a partnership, the names and residential addresses of each general partner and each limited partner owning ten percent interest or more in the partnership either directly or beneficially shall also be given. 
b.  A description of the services to be provided. 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the building where the business will be conducted; also the name, address and telephone number of the building manager if different from the owner. 
d.  The location, mailing address and the telephone numbers where the business is to be conducted. 
e.  Written proof that the applicant (if individual or partnership) and all managers are at least 18 years of age. 
f.  A copy of identification from each manager, owner and from each applicant such as driver's license (if an individual), partnership agreement and certificate (if a partnership) or certificate of good standing from the state (if a corporation). 
g.  Business history: 
1.  Brief history of past massage establishment experience; 
2.  Whether any previous massage establishment associated with the applicant had its license suspended, revoked, denied and the reasons for such action. 
h.  The name and address of any other massage business or establishment owned (partially or wholly) or operated by any person or entity controlled by the applicant, owner or manager. 
i.  The names and addresses of each person (if then known) who will be employed at the massage establishments and copies of a state-issued massage therapist license for each employee who will be engaged in the practice of massage therapy. 
j.  A description of any other businesses to be operated on the same premises as the massage establishment or on any adjoining or nearby premises owned or controlled by the applicant, owner and manager. 
k.  Authorization for the city, its agents and employees to seek information and conduct a background investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications for the applicant for the license. 
l.  Such identification and information necessary to verify the truth of the matters required to be set forth in the application. 
m.  The annual license fee for each massage establishment which shall be established from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
n.  List all criminal convictions (both in-state and out-of-state) other than traffic violations including the date of the conviction, the court the conviction was in, what the conviction was for and the case number of the conviction, and the reasons therefore. 
o.  Provide a printout from I.C.H.A.T. of Michigan Criminal History (Internet Criminal History Tool). Go to www.michigan.org and run your criminal history by following the ICHAT link. 
(2)  The applicant shall notify the city clerk in writing of each change in any of the data required to be furnished by this license within ten days of such change. 
(3)  The license granted hereunder shall be for one year beginning January 1 of each year, except the initial license granted hereunder shall be valid from the date of issuance until the following December 31. A license granted hereunder is nontransferable. 
(4)  Upon sale or transfer of any interest (in excess of ten percent) in a massage establishment, the license shall be void. A new application shall be made by any person desiring to own or operate a massage establishment. 
(5)  The applicant, owner or manager of the massage establishment shall display the license in a conspicuous place at all times so that it may be readily seen by persons entering the premises. 
(6)  No massage establishment licensed under this article shall operate under any name or conduct its business under any designation not specified in the license. 
(d)  Responsibilities of massage establishment. It shall be the responsibility of an owner, manager, operator or licensee hereunder in charge or in control of a massage establishment to comply with the following: 
(1)  In the event that the licensee wishes to obtain a license for an ensuing year, such licensee shall file its application in accordance with this article as the case may be, at least 14 days before the expiration of the current license. If the applicant fails to comply with this requirement, the city clerk shall not be required to grant or deny the license before the expiration of the current license. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fraudulently make use of, to his/her own or other's benefit, a license issued to him/her or another in accordance with this article. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to counterfeit or forge, or to deface or otherwise alter a license issued under the provisions of this article. 
(4)  A license issued under this article is not transferable, separable, or divisible, and the authority conferred only upon the individuals required to submit personal information pursuant to subsection (3). 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating an establishment to permit or allow an employee to violate any of the terms of this article while on the premises of the establishment. 
(6)  No persons shall sell, permit, consume, give or provide or cause to be sold, given or provided, any alcoholic beverage on the premises of any massage establishment. 
(7)  No medical treatment outside normal massage therapy duties shall be given or dispensed at a massage establishment. 
(8)  No massage establishment shall massage or service any person under the age of 17 except when such a person is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian or under written order by a licensed physician, osteopath, chiropractor, psychiatrist or registered physical therapist, such order being dated and in possession of the massage therapist giving the massage. 
(9)  It shall be unlawful for any massage establishment to offer any of the following acts or conducts: adamitism, anilingus, cunniilingus, coprophilia, fellation, flagellation, masturbation, sadism, sexual intercourse, sodomy, urolagnia, or any intentional stimulation or manipulation of sexual or genital parts of the human body for purposes of sexual arousal or stimulation or any other activity of a sexual nature prohibited by state law. 
(10)  No massage establishments shall be kept open between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(e)  Physical establishment standards. Each massage establishment shall comply with the following standards: 
(1)  All tables, tubs, shower stalls and floors (except reception and administrative areas) shall be made of nonporous materials which may be readily disinfected. 
(2)  Closed cabinets shall be provided and used for the storage of clean linen, towels and other materials used in connection with administering massages. 
(3)  Closed containers shall be provided for all soiled linen, towels and waste materials. 
(4)  At least one plumbed sink within the massage establishment. Additionally, each individual area in which massage is practiced shall be equipped with a hand-sanitizing facility equipped with: 
a.  Running water and soap; 
b.  Antibacterial hand wipes; 
c.  Waterless hand sanitizers; or 
d.  Other commercially acceptable means of hand-washing. 
(5)  Lavatories and shower stalls (if provided) shall be located as to ensure privacy between the massage establishment and any other business or use. 
(6)  All the general special use criteria in section 9.05 of the Zoning Ordinance are satisfied. 
(7)  All equipment, shower stalls, toilets, lavatories and any other such accouterments shall be regularly treated with disinfectants and shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
(8)  No part of the licensed premises shall be used for or connected with any bedroom or sleeping quarters; nor shall any person sleep in a massage establishment except for a limited period incidental to and directly related to massage or bath. No beds, water mattresses, cots, or other such equipment designated for sleeping shall be permitted on the premises. 
(9)  All massage establishments are public places and during business hours shall not lock or obstruct the exits and entrances to the establishment or otherwise prevent free ingress and egress of persons. 
(10)  Minimum lighting shall be provided in accordance with the city building and county electrical codes. 
(11)  Minimum ventilation shall be provided in accordance with the city building code. 
(12)  Hot and cold running water shall be provided at all times. 
(f)  Sanitary standards. Each massage establishment shall comply with the following standards: 
(1)  All personnel shall wash his or her hands in hot water with soap before giving any service or treatment to each separate patron. 
(2)  All towels, tissues, sheets or other coverings shall be used singularly for each patron and discarded for laundry or disposal immediately after use. Clean and sanitary towels and linens shall be provided for each patron of the establishment. No common use of towel or linens shall be permitted. 
(3)  Non-disposable tools of the trade shall be disinfected after each use upon a patron. 
(4)  All massage therapists shall, at all times, wear clean outer garments whose use is restricted to the massage establishment. The garments shall be opaque and shall cover the torso, legs and the sexual and genital parts of the employee's body. 
(5)  The sexual and genital areas of patrons, customers or invitees must be covered by towels, cloths, or opaque garments at all times when in the presence of any massage therapist or employee of the massage establishment. 
(g)  Denial, revocation, or suspension of license. 
(1)  Any applicant for a license hereunder may be denied by the city clerk if there are any false statements set forth in the application and any license granted herein may be revoked by the city council for violation of any other provision of this article or any other city ordinance or state statute, or upon a determination that the continued operation under an existing license shall be contrary to the public health, safety or welfare. Appeal of the denial or revocation of a license by the city clerk shall be made to the city council. 
(2)  Before the city council revokes a license issued herein or upon appeal from denial of a license by the city clerk, the city council shall cause written notice to be sent by certified mail to the licensee or applicant affected, at the address stated in the license or application informing such person of the right to a hearing upon the request. If the licensee does not request a hearing within 14 days of the date said notice was sent, the license may be forthwith revoked or the denial of the application affirmed. If the licensee requests a hearing before the city council in regard to said proposed revocation or denial, said hearing shall be held within 21 days after the date of the written request. If the licensee or applicant is a massage establishment, the owner of the premises according to the latest tax assessment roll where such establishment is or plans to locate shall also be sent by certified mail a notice of the hearing. 
(3)  Any license issued by the city may be immediately suspended by the city manager or duly appointed city official, if it is determined that the licensee has violated or someone at or upon the licensed location has violated the city ordinance or state law and that continued operation under the license is contrary to the public health, safety and welfare. A licensee shall have the right to a hearing before the city council on any license suspension by the city manager. The city manager shall cause a written notice to be personally delivered or sent by certified mail to the licensee, at the address stated in the license or application informing the licensee of the suspension and the licensee's right to a hearing upon request. If the licensee does not file a written request within 14 days after receipt of the notice, the city council may forthwith confirm such suspension or revoke or reinstate the license. If the licensee requests a hearing before the city council, the hearing shall be held within 21 days after the date of the written request. Notice of the hearing shall be sent to the licensee by certified mail at the address stated in the license. If the licensee is a massage establishment, the owner of the license premises according to the latest tax assessment roll shall also be sent by certified mail a notice of the hearing. 
(4)  Both the city and the licensee shall be afforded a reasonable opportunity to present evidence on the issue at the hearing. In the event a license is revoked herein the licensee or a substantially similar or related licensee shall not be granted a new license nor shall a license be granted for the same premises, for a period of three years from the date of the revocation. Upon suspension or revocation of any license or permit, the fee therefore shall not be refunded. The action taken by the city council shall be final. 
(h)  Inspection. Every establishment operated as a licensed massage establishment shall be open for inspection by duly authorized representatives of any city department including but not limited to the department of public safety as well as any other department concerned with the licensing and supervision of such establishments during operating hours for the purpose of enforcing any provision of this article or any other ordinances or regulations of the city relating to public health, safety and welfare. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse entry by city representatives to the premises in which a massage establishment is being operated for the purpose of making lawful inspections. 
(i)  Renewal. The license to operate a massage establishment shall be renewed at least 14 days prior to the date of expiration. The license shall be renewed if the applicant submits a sworn affidavit that the matters contained in the original application are correct and indicates any changes necessary to otherwise comply with the requirements of this article. 
(j)  Penalty. Violations of this section shall be considered municipal civil infractions. 
(Ord. No. 797 , § 1, 2-5-18) 
Secs. 22-51-22-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MOBILE FOOD VENDING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 798 , § 2, adopted May 7, 2018 set out provisions intended for use as Art. III, §§ 22-38-22-46. Inasmuch as said sections already exist, said provisions have been redesignated as Art. IV, §§ 22-61-22-69, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 22-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms shall be defined for the purposes of this chapter. As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    Mobile food vending means vending, serving, or offering for sale food or beverages from a mobile food vending unit, along with ancillary sales of branded items consistent with the food or mobile food vendor, such as a tee shirt that bears the name of the company, restaurant, or organization engaged in mobile food vending. 
    Mobile food vending unit means a vehicle with a self-contained kitchen, equipped to create, prepare, or package food for the purpose of vending, service, or offering for sale. 
    Mobile food vendor means any individual, company, restaurant, or organization operating a mobile food vending unit. 
    Operates means engaging in activities associated with the conduct of business, including setup and takedown and/or hours of operation and locations where the mobile food vending units are allowed to be open for business. 
( Ord. No. 798 , § 2, 5-7-18) 
Sec. 22-62. - Permit required. 
(a)  No mobile food vendor shall operate a mobile food vending unit without a permit issued by the city authorizing such operation. The city clerk shall prescribe the form of available permits and the application for such permits. The city council shall, by resolution, establish appropriate fees for the available permits. 
(b)  All permits shall be prominently displayed on the mobile food vending unit. No vending through a mobile food vending unit of food or other human consumables shall be permitted unless it meets the definition of mobile food vending as defined by this chapter. 
(c)  No permit shall be required for a mobile food vending unit which is operated in conjunction with a community event approved by the city council. The regulations in sections 22-66 and 22-67 shall still apply. 
( Ord. No. 798 , § 2, 5-7-18) 
Sec. 22-63. - Duration of permit; nontransferability. 
    Permits issued by the city clerk shall be valid only for the calendar year in which they are issued and for the mobile food vending unit identified on the permit. Any permit issued under this article is nontransferable. 
( Ord. No. 798 , § 2, 5-7-18) 
Sec. 22-64. - Application for permit. 
    Any mobile food vendor desiring to engage in mobile food vending in the city shall submit a completed application to the city clerk for a permit under this chapter. The application must include all required information and all required documentation, such as insurance, as required by the city. There shall be at least two categories of permits: permits valid for a period of one calendar year and permits limited to a single event. 
    The applicant shall truthfully state, in full, all information requested on the application for a permit issued by the city clerk's office. Additionally, the applicant shall provide all documentation, such as proof of insurance, as required by this chapter or by resolution of the city council. The application for a permit shall be accompanied by a fee as defined in this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 798 , § 2, 5-7-18) 
Sec. 22-65. - Fees. 
    The application fee, in an amount established by resolution of the city council, shall be required upon submission of the application. Regardless of when the application is submitted during the calendar year, the fee shall be required in full, and the fee shall not be prorated. Once the permit has been issued, the application fee shall be nonrefundable. 
( Ord. No. 798 , § 2, 5-7-18) 
Sec. 22-66. - Requirements. 
    Any mobile food vendor engaging in mobile food vending shall comply with the following requirements. 
(1)  Mobile food vending units may operate on private property on parcels zoned I-1, I-2, I-4, PB, OS, C-1, C-2, C-3, D-1, and D-2 if in compliance with the applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Mobile food vendors shall not operate on city-owned property or on public streets except at such times and in such locations permitted by resolution of the city council. When mobile food vendors are permitted to operate on public streets, no food service shall be allowed on the driving lane side of the mobile food vending unit. To the extent it becomes necessary to designate specific mobile food vendors who may occupy a public location at any given time, city staff shall develop policies or practices for making such determinations. 
(3)  No food shall be sold, prepared, or displayed outside of the mobile food vending unit while on the location noted on the permit. 
(4)  Mobile food vendors shall provide appropriate waste and recycling receptacles at the site of the unit and remove all litter, debris and other wastes attributable to the mobile food vendor or customers on a daily basis. 
(5)  Mobile food vendors shall not use any flashing, blinking or strobe lights, or similar effects to draw attention to the mobile food vending unit; all exterior lights over 60 watts shall contain opaque hood shields to direct the illumination downward. 
(6)  Mobile food vendors shall not use loud music, amplification devices, or any other audible methods to gain attention which causes a disruption or safety hazard as determined by the city. 
(7)  There shall be no signage used by mobile food vendors except for what is allowed on the mobile food vending unit itself in accordance with the city Code. 
(8)  When operating on city property or public streets, mobile food vendors are prohibited from locating, placing, or putting personal property outside of the mobile food vending unit, including but not limited to dining furniture, fixtures, and equipment. 
(9)  No mobile food vendor shall utilize any electricity or power without the prior written authorization of the power customer; no power cable or similar device shall be extended at or across any street or sidewalk except in a safe manner. 
(10)  Mobile food vendors shall comply with all applicable city laws, regulations, and ordinances, including those regulating noise, signage, and loitering. 
(11)  Mobile food vendors shall not represent the granting of a permit under this chapter as an endorsement of the city. 
( Ord. No. 798 , § 2, 5-7-18) 
Sec. 22-67. - Other permits. 
    A permit obtained under this chapter shall not relieve any mobile food vendor of the responsibility for obtaining any other permit or authorization required by any other resolution, ordinance, statute, or administrative rule. 
( Ord. No. 798 , § 2, 5-7-18) 
Sec. 22-68. - Complaints; appeals; revocation of permit. 
(a)  If a written complaint is filed with the city clerk alleging a mobile food vendor has violated the provisions of this chapter, the city clerk shall promptly send a copy of the written complaint to the mobile food vendor together with a notice that an investigation will be made by the city clerk, with the assistance of other city departments, as required, as to the truth of the complaint. The mobile food vendor shall be invited to respond to the complaint and present evidence and respond to evidence produced by the investigation. If the city clerk, after reviewing all relevant material, finds the complaint to be supported by a preponderance of the evidence, the complaint shall be certified. 
(b)  The city clerk shall revoke the permit of any mobile food vendor engaged in mobile food vending who ceases to meet any requirement of this chapter or violates any other federal, state, or local law, ordinance, or regulation; makes a false statement on the permit application; or conducts activity in a manner that is adverse to the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare. Any revocation shall have immediate effect or remain in effect unless and until reversed on an appeal. 
(c)  If a permit is denied or revoked by the city clerk or if a written complaint is certified pursuant to this chapter, the applicant or holder of the permit may appeal to the city council in writing. The city council shall make a written determination, after reviewing evidence related to the appeal, as to whether the denial, revocation, or complaint is valid. If the city council determines that the denial, revocation, or complaint is valid as supported by a preponderance of the evidence, the action of the city clerk shall be sustained. The applicant may appeal the decision of the city council to a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  Immediately upon such revocation, the city clerk shall provide written notice to the permit holder by certified mail to the address indicated on the application. The permit to operate shall become immediately null and void upon revocation. 
( Ord. No. 798 , § 2, 5-7-18) 
Sec. 22-69. - Civil infraction. 
    Any person who violates this chapter shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction subject to a fine not to exceed $500.00. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed to be a separate violation. 
( Ord. No. 798 , § 2, 5-7-18) 
Chapter 26 - CEMETERIES 
  

Sec. 26-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Burial space means a lot or portion of a lot in any cemetery designated and maintained for the interment of a human body or bodies, and for no other purpose. 
    Cemetery means Oakwood Cemetery as heretofore established, and any other public cemetery owned, managed or controlled by the city. 
    Owner means any person owning or possessing the privilege, license or right of interment in any burial space. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 1, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-2. - Authority to acquire, manage. 
    The city may acquire, hold and own such cemetery or public burial place or places either within or without the limits of the city, as in the opinion of the council shall be necessary for the public welfare, and suitable for the convenience of the inhabitants, and shall limit such interment therein to such cemetery as the council may prescribe. 
(Ord. No. 111, § 1, 1942; Code 1968, § 7-2) 
Sec. 26-3. - Authority to raise, appropriate money. 
    The council may, within the limits of law, raise and appropriate such sums as may be necessary for the purchase of cemetery grounds and for the improvement, adornment, protection and care thereof. 
(Ord. No. 111, § 2, 1942; Code 1968, § 7-3) 
Sec. 26-4. - Supervision by council. 
    The cemeteries which have been or may hereafter be established by the city and maintained either within or without its limits shall be under the management, supervision and care of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 2, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-4) 
Sec. 26-5. - Preparation, filing of plats. 
    The council shall, if necessary, cause plats of such cemeteries, showing and designating lots, drives, walks and landscaping, to be prepared and kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 2, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-5) 
Sec. 26-6. - Adoption of rules and regulations. 
    The city council shall, from time to time, make and adopt by resolution such rules and regulations for the burial of the dead, the care, improvement and protection of the grounds, mausoleums, monuments and appurtenances and the orderly conduct of persons visiting, as may be deemed necessary. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 3, 1-6-64; Ord. No. 194, § 1, 12-19-66; Code 1968, § 7-6) 
Sec. 26-7. - Appeals from rules and regulations. 
    Where there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the cemetery rules and regulations, or where a unique problem not covered by the cemetery rules and regulations arises, the parties affected thereby may appeal to the cemetery board of appeals, which is hereby established for such purposes and empowered to render a final decision in all such appeals. The cemetery board of appeals shall consist of four qualified persons to be appointed annually by the city council and one voting member of the city council to be appointed annually by the mayor, with approval of the council, and shall establish its own rules of procedure providing a fair and impartial hearing to all interested parties before rendering its decision. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 3, 1-6-64; Ord. No. 194, § 1, 12-19-66; Code 1968, § 7-7; Ord. No. 406, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 472, § 1, 2-4-91) 
Sec. 26-8. - Sale, transfer of lots. 
    The city clerk shall attend to the sale and transfer of all cemetery lots, and all certificates of right of burial therefor shall be executed on behalf of the city by the city clerk. Such certificates shall be delivered by the city clerk to each owner upon payment to the city clerk of the required amount, or upon receipt of proper proof of transfer, and shall convey only the right of interment subject to such rules and regulations as may have been or shall hereafter be adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 4, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-8) 
Sec. 26-9. - Prices of lots, services. 
    The city council shall fix by resolution the price of lots and other services incidental to cemetery operation. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 2, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-9) 
Sec. 26-10. - Register of interments. 
    The city clerk shall cause to be kept a register of all interments in which shall appear the name of the deceased, the date and place of interment and such other information as may be required. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 3, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-10) 
Sec. 26-11. - Lot records required. 
    The city clerk shall keep proper records in which the certificates of right of burial and transfer instruments to all burial spaces shall be recorded at length. In connection with all such records, the city clerk shall also keep a general index in which shall be noted, alphabetically, the name of the owner of each burial space in city cemeteries, and a cross reference index by burial space number. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 5, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-11) 
Sec. 26-12. - Labor charges for work in cemeteries. 
    The city clerk shall charge and collect on behalf of the city such fees for work performed in city cemeteries as may be from time to time fixed by resolution of the city council. All such fees shall be paid directly to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 6, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-12) 
Sec. 26-13. - Persons authorized to work in cemeteries. 
    No person other than an authorized employee of the city shall perform any work in city cemeteries, unless such work is done under the supervision of authorized city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 6, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-13) 
Sec. 26-14. - Perpetual care fund continued; assets; administration. 
(a)  The cemetery perpetual care fund, heretofore established, is hereby continued. There shall be added to such fund all sums paid to the city in accordance with the specified terms and conditions of perpetual care contracts, amounts realized from the sale of lots, parts of lots, and single graves in city cemeteries, and amounts realized from the interment charges (burial fees) in accordance with the following chart: 
(1) Lot sales ..... 100 percent to perpetual care fund. (2) Burial Fees ..... 40 percent to perpetual care fund; 
60 percent to cemetery operations. (3) Foundation Fees ..... 40 percent to perpetual care fund; 
60 percent to cemetery operations.  
(b)  The cemetery perpetual care fund shall be administered by the city council, and the city treasurer shall have custody of all money, credits and securities constituting such fund. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 7, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-14; Ord. No. 355, § 1, 10-20-80; Ord. No. 455, § 1, 5-7-90; Ord. No. 552, § 1, 7-24-95) 
Sec. 26-15. - Investment of perpetual care fund. 
    Any part of the principal of the perpetual care fund may be invested in bonds of the city, or any obligation of the government of the United States, or in insured savings accounts maintained in any financial institution in the city. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 8, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-15) 
Sec. 26-16. - Transferring, encumbering perpetual care fund. 
    No part of the cemetery perpetual care fund shall be transferred to any other fund, nor encumbered or used except as authorized in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 9, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-16) 
Sec. 26-17. - Use of perpetual care fund. 
    The income from the perpetual care fund shall be expended only for the following purposes: 
(1)  To perpetually maintain and care for lots located in city cemeteries which are covered by perpetual care contracts with the city. 
(2)  The remainder of the income, if any, may be used for general maintenance, repair and upkeep of city cemeteries. 
(3)  The principal of the perpetual care fund may be used for reasonable capital improvements in city cemeteries which will provide additional burial spaces to the extent that the use of such principal shall not substantially impair the earning capacity of the balance of the fund and after approval by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 171, § 9, 1-6-64; Code 1968, § 7-17; Ord. No. 371, § 1, 9-20-82) 
Chapter 30 - COMMUNITY ANTENNA TELEVISION SYSTEM[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

ARTICLE I. - VIDEO PROVIDERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 705, adopted May 7, 2007, amended the Code by repealing former art. I, §§ 30-1-30-29, and adding a new art. I. Former art. I pertained to franchise regulations, and derived from Ord. No. 547, adopted June 19, 1995; and Ord. No. 685, adopted March 21, 2005. 

Sec. 30-1. - Title and purpose. 
(a)  Short title. This article shall be known as the "City of Saline Video Providers Ordinance." 
(b)  Declaration of findings and purpose. 
(1)  The city council finds that cable systems permanently occupy and extensively make use of scarce and valuable city public rights-of-way in a manner different from the way in which the general public uses them. Video service providers also travel city streets and rights-of-way in order to transact local business. The city council finds that public convenience, safety, and general welfare can best be served by exercising the police powers vested in the city to protect the public and to ensure that any video franchise which issues is operated in the public interest. 
(2)  Further, the city finds that the average American home has a television on for nearly eight (8) hours per day. This average is much higher than the average time listening to the radio or surfing the Internet. Consequently, video emergency alerts should be included in any effort made by the city to distribute emergency messages affecting city residents. 
(3)  Further, it is determined that wireline competition in the delivery of video and other services delivered by cable systems is desired by the city, as such competition will lower prices for city residents, improve customer service, and increase innovation. 
(4)  Further, while competition in the delivery of cable services is desired and encouraged, no wireline cable competition currently exists within the city. As a consequence, cable prices in the city continue to increase at a pace greater than inflation, the regulation of customer service in the city is still deemed necessary due to a significant number of complaints, and a low level of relative customer satisfaction prevails. 
(5)  Further, attacks on the public while congregated within public spaces and attacks on children while at school have recently occurred at a disturbing rate, and it is imperative that the city require the development of cable systems that are reasonably capable of delivering emergency information to these public spaces. 
(6)  Further, the frequency of in-person interactions between a video service provider's employees and its subscribers will increase, as video service providers continue to offer a greater number of services to subscribers. 
(7)  Given the lack of wireline cable competition in the city, the city finds that it can improve and protect the general welfare and public interest of city residents by adopting policies and regulations pursuant to the city's police powers which regulate the manner in which cable operators transact local business within the city. 
(8)  In light of the foregoing, the following goals, among others, underlie the provisions set forth in this chapter: 
a.  Cable should be available to as many city residents as possible. 
b.  Wireline cable competition should be encouraged and should be made available to as many city residents as possible. 
c.  Cable systems within the city should be constructed in a manner that permits the city to interrupt video programming in the event that an emergency message needs to be transmitted to city residents. 
d.  Cable systems within the city should be constructed in a manner that permits emergency messages and other information related to public safety to be exchanged privately between public buildings, including police and fire stations. 
e.  Cable systems within the city should be constructed in a manner that permits the delivery of emergency messages to public classrooms and other public spaces where the public congregates and televisions may regularly be in use. 
f.  Video service providers should not utilize the public rights-of-way to transact local business in the city in a manner which may deprive city subscribers of rights and interests that they may otherwise enjoy under the law. 
g.  A cable operator should pay fair compensation to the city for the occupation and use of the local public rights-of-way. 
(c)  The city council intends that all provisions set forth in this chapter be construed broadly to serve the public interest and the foregoing public purposes, and that any franchise which may issue be construed to include the foregoing findings and public purposes as integral parts thereof. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended. The word shall is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Additional insureds shall have the meaning defined in section 30-14(a)(4). 
    Affiliate shall mean any entity controlling, controlled by or under common control with the entity in question. 
    Basic cable service means any service tier which includes the retransmission of local television broadcast signals and the PEG channels. 
    Cable Act means Title VI of the Communications Act of 1934 as amended, 47 USC § 521 et seq. 
    Cable channel or channel means a portion of the capacity on a cable system which is capable of delivering a television channel while using the same transmission technology as is applied to the other channels appearing on the same service tier. 
    Cable operator means any person or group of persons who provides cable service over a cable system and directly or through one or more affiliates owns a significant interest in such cable systems, or who otherwise controls or is responsible for, through any arrangement, the management and operation of such a cable system. 
    Cable service means the one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming, or other programming service and subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection of such video programming or other programming service. 
    Cable communications system, cable system, or system means a facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control equipment that provides video services which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such term does not include: 
(1)  A facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; 
(2)  A facility that serves subscribers without using any public rights-of-way; 
(3)  A facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II of the Communications Act of 1934, 47 U.S.C. § 201 et seq., except that such facility shall be considered a cable system to the extent that such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers; 
(4)  An open video system that complies with 47 U.S.C. §573; or 
(5)  Any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility system. 
    City means the City of Saline, and all the territory within its territorial corporate limits. 
    City manager means the manager of the city or his/her designee. 
    Commercially impracticable means, with respect to any requirement applicable to the grantee, that it is commercially impracticable for the grantee to comply with such requirement as a result of a change in conditions which is beyond the control of the grantee and the nonoccurrence of which was a basic assumption on which the requirement was based. 
    Council means the city council of the City of Saline. 
    Educational or governmental access facilities means channel capacity designated for educational or governmental use, and facilities and equipment for the use of such capacity. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission, Washington, D.C. 
    Franchising entity means the council. 
    Grantee means a video service provider which has sought and received a video service local franchise agreement and which operates in accordance with this chapter. 
    Gross revenues shall mean all consideration of any kind or nature, including, without limitation, cash, credits, property, and in-kind contributions received by the provider from the operation of the cable system to provide video services within the jurisdiction of the franchising entity. 
(1)  Gross revenues shall include all of the following: 
a.  All charges and fees paid by subscribers for the provision of video service, including equipment rental, late fees, insufficient funds fees, fees attributable to video service when sold individually or as part of a package or bundle, or functionally integrated, with services other than video service. 
b.  Any franchise fee imposed on the provider that is passed on to subscribers. 
c.  Compensation received by the provider for promotion or exhibition of any products or services over the video service. 
d.  Revenue received by the provider as compensation for carriage of video programming on that provider's video service. 
e.  All revenue derived from compensation arrangements for advertising shown within the local franchise area. 
f.  Any advertising commissions paid to an affiliated third party for video service advertising. 
(2)  Gross revenues do not include any of the following: 
a.  Any revenue not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt net of any recoveries of bad debt. 
b.  Refunds, rebates, credits, or discounts to subscribers or a city to the extent not already offset by subdivision (a) and to the extent the refund, rebate, credit, or discount is attributable to the video service. 
c.  Any revenues received by the provider or its affiliates from the provision of services or capabilities other than video service, including telecommunications services, information services, and services, capabilities, and applications that may be sold as part of a package or bundle, or functionally integrated, with video service. 
d.  Any revenues received by the provider or its affiliates for the provision of directory or internet advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and electronic publishing. 
e.  Any amounts attributable to the provision of video service to customers at no charge, including the provision of such service to public institutions without charge. 
f.  Any tax, fee, or assessment of general applicability imposed on the customer or the transaction by a federal, state, or local government or any other governmental entity, collected by the provider, and required to be remitted to the taxing entity, including sales and use taxes. 
g.  Any forgone revenue from the provision of video service at no charge to any person, except that any forgone revenue exchanged for trades, barters, services, or other items of value shall be included in gross revenue. 
h.  Sales of capital assets or surplus equipment. 
i.  Reimbursement by programmers of marketing costs actually incurred by the provider for the introduction of new programming. 
j.  The sale of video service for resale to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing that it will resell the service and pay a franchise fee with respect to the service. 
(3)  In the case of a video service that is bundled or integrated functionally with other services, capabilities, or applications, the portion of the video provider's revenue attributable to the other services, capabilities, or applications shall be included in gross revenue unless the provider can reasonably identify the division or exclusion of the revenue from its books and records that are kept in the regular course of business. 
(4)  In the event that grantee provides services bundled in a package and offers said bundle(s) at a price discounted from the price that would otherwise apply if the services were purchased individually, then grantee shall not exclude from its gross revenues any amount greater than that amount calculated by applying that percentage which is equivalent to the overall discount of the entire bundled package against the full retail value of that service in the sold bundle which generates gross revenue (for purposes of clarification and without altering the aforesaid obligation, if a package price reflects an overall discount of 15 percent, then for the purpose of calculating gross revenues, no more than a 15 percent discount may be taken against the full retail value of the services in the sold bundle which generate gross revenue). 
(5)  Revenue of an affiliate shall be included in the calculation of gross revenues to the extent the treatment of the revenue as revenue of the affiliate has the effect of evading the payment of franchise fees which would otherwise be paid for video service. 
    IPTV means Internet protocol television. 
    Incumbent video provider means a cable operator serving cable subscribers or a telecommunications provider providing video services through the provider's existing telephone exchange boundaries in a particular franchise area within the city on the effective date of this chapter. 
    Normal operating conditions means those service conditions which are within the control of grantee. Those conditions which are normally not within the control of grantee include, but are not limited to, natural disasters, civil disturbances, power outages, telephone network outages, and severe or unusual weather conditions. Those conditions which normally are within the control of grantee include, but are not limited to, special promotions, pay-per-view events, rate increases, regular or seasonal demand periods, changes in the billing cycle, and repairs, rebuilds, maintenance or upgrade of the cable system. 
    PEG channels shall have the meaning set forth in section 30-9. 
    Person means an individual, partnership, limited partnership, association, joint stock company, trust, corporation, or governmental entity. 
    Public rights-of-way means the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, public sidewalk, alley, waterway, or utility easements dedicated for compatible purposes. "Public rights-of-way" shall not include property of the city which is not a dedicated public right-of-way, street, highway, or alley necessary and pertinent to a cable system. 
    Service tier means a category of cable service or other services provided by the grantee and for which a separate rate is charged by the grantee. 
    Service interruption means the loss of picture or sound on one or more cable channels by one or more subscribers. 
    State means the State of Michigan or political subdivision or agency thereof. 
    Subscriber means a person or organization located within the city whose premises are physically wired to receive any transmission from the system. 
    Video programming means programming provided by, or generally considered comparable to programming provided by, a television broadcast station. 
    Video service means video programming, cable services, IPTV, or OVS provided through facilities located at least in part in the public rights-of-way without regard to delivery technology, including internet protocol technology. "Video service" does not mean any video programming provided by a commercial mobile service provider defined in 47 USC § 332(d) or provided solely as part of, and via, a service that enables users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other services offered solely over the public internet. 
    Video service local franchise agreement, franchise, or franchise agreement means the separate agreement by which a franchise is granted to the grantee by the city or by operation of governing law. 
    Video service provider or provider means a person who provides video services pursuant to a franchise and in compliance with this article. 
    Video service provider fee means the amount paid by a video service provider under section 30-7, and shall be the total of the right-of-way access fee and the PEG fee, as those terms are defined in that section 30-7. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-3. - Franchise procedure. 
(a)  Franchise required. 
(1)  No person shall offer video service in the city without such person having first obtained a local video service franchise agreement. 
(2)  No person shall use, occupy or traverse the city streets, alleys, lanes, avenues, boulevards, sidewalks, bridges, viaducts, rights-of-way or any other public place or public rights-of-way in the city or any extensions thereof or additions thereto, whether on, above, or under the surface of the ground, for the purpose of offering video services without first obtaining a local video service franchise agreement. 
(b)  Franchise application. Subject to applicable law: 
(1)  A person wishing to provide video service within the city shall file a written application with the city clerk's office via regular first class mail return receipt requested or via a nationally recognized overnight delivery service. Copies of the application shall be provided concurrently and via the same delivery method to the city administrator, the city attorney, and such additional persons as the city may designate from time-to-time. Minimally, said application shall include the following information: 
a.  The name of the applicant; 
b.  The address and telephone number of the provider's principal place of business; 
c.  The name of the applicant's executive officers and any specific persons authorized to represent the provider before the city; 
d.  If the provider is not an incumbent video provider, the specific date on which the provider expects to provide video services in the area identified under subdivision e.; 
e.  An exact description of the video service area to be served in the city, as identified by a geographic information system digital boundary meeting or exceeding national map accuracy standards. For applicants with 1,000,000 or more access lines in this state using telecommunications facilities to provide video services, the footprint shall be identified in terms of entire wire centers or exchanges. An incumbent video provider shall provide right-of-way related information comparable to that required by a permit under the metropolitan extension telecommunications rights-of-way oversight act, 2002 PA 48, MCL 484.3101 to 484.3120; 
f.  A certification that the applicant will pay the video service provider fees required by section 30-7 herein; 
g.  A certification that the applicant will file in a timely manner with the FCC all forms required by that agency in advance of offering video service; 
h.  A certification that the applicant agrees to comply with all valid and enforceable federal, state and local statutes and regulations, which shall be deemed to include those contained in this article; 
i.  A certification that the applicant agrees to comply with all valid and enforceable local regulations regarding the use and occupation of public rights-of-way, including those promulgated pursuant to the police power of the city; 
j.  A requirement that the applicant comply with all FCC requirements involving the distribution and notification of federal, state and local emergency messages over the applicant's proposed cable system; 
k.  A certification that the provider will comply with the public, education, and government access programming requirements of section 30-9; 
l.  A certification that the applicant will comply with all customer service rules of the FCC under 47 CFR 76.309(c); said certification shall be deemed as the applicant's acknowledgment of the city's right to enforce and later amend said customer service standards, as set forth in the FCC order which promulgated the aforesaid regulation (Report & Order, In the Matter of Implementation of Section 8 of the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 , FCC 93-145 (Released April 7, 1993). 
(c)  The application shall be accompanied by such nonrefundable fee as may set by the city council which shall be used to cover expenses, direct or indirect, incurred by the city in processing said application. 
(d)  Applications shall be in such form and contain such information and supportive documentation as the city may require, and said applications may be obtained by an applicant from the city clerk. 
(e)  If any of the information contained in a franchise application or in a subsequently-issued franchise changes, the provider shall promptly notify the city. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-4. - Application process; city administrator's action. 
    Subject to applicable law: 
(1)  Upon receiving the application and any applicable fee, the city manager or his or her designee shall promptly investigate and review the application and determine whether the application is complete; 
(2)  The city manager shall inform the applicant as to whether its application is complete or incomplete not later than fifteen (15) business days following receipt of the application by the city clerk's office. At the same time, the city manager shall inform the applicant of the number of PEG channels required by the city as set forth in section 30-9 herein. 
(3)  In the event that the application is complete, the city manager may execute the application or take such other action with respect to the application as permitted under governing law. If further action is taken by the city manager, said action shall be taken not more than thirty (30) days following receipt of the complete application by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-5. - Permission, franchise. 
(a)  Nonexclusive. All franchises which issue subsequent to the effective date of this article shall be nonexclusive and subject to all the terms and conditions contained herein, and to all generally applicable provisions in the City Charter, the City Code and to city ordinances as from time to time in effect. 
(b)  Consents deemed given. Any franchise issued subsequent to the effective date of this article shall, subject to the provisions of this chapter, be deemed to provide: 
(1)  The city's consent for grantee to access, and for its cable system to occupy, the public rights-of-way for the delivery of video service, as required by article VII, section 29 of the Michigan Constitution; and
