(2)  The city's consent for a grantee to travel the public rights-of-way in order to transact local business, as required by article VII, section 29 of the Michigan Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-6. - Term of franchise. 
    Length. Any franchise which issues after the effective date of this article shall be in effect for a period of ten years after its effective date. A franchise may be renewed in the manner provided by governing law. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-7. - Video service provider fee. 
(a)  Video service provider fee. Each grantee shall pay to city throughout the term of its franchise a video service provider fee. The video service provider fee shall be defined as the total of: 
(1)  An amount equal to five percent of grantee's gross revenues (the "right-of-way fee"); and 
(2)  A public, educational and government access fee ("PEG fee") which shall be comprised of: 
a.  Two percent of grantee's gross revenues; and 
b.  Such additional PEG fees as may be required of a particular grantee by the city pursuant to section 30-7(b) (the "pro-rata fee"). 
All PEG fees paid by grantee are received by city pursuant to § 622(g)(2)(C) of the Cable Act, and will not qualify as a setoff to any franchise fee or right-of-way fee paid to the city. 
(1)  Due date. The video service provider fee shall be paid within 45 days of the end of each calendar quarter, and shall be based upon gross revenues received during such calendar quarter and upon the number of basic service tier subscribers held by the grantee as of the last day of such calendar quarter (the latter in the case of the pro-rata PEG fee); 
(2)  Report. Each payment shall be accompanied by a written report to city verified by an officer of grantee, containing an accurate statement of grantee's gross revenues, the number of basic service tier subscribers held by the grantee as of the last day of the particular calendar quarter, and the computation of the payment amount. Such report shall be submitted in the form attached as exhibit 1, following this article. 
(3)  Audit rights. City may audit grantee (or any entity affiliated with grantee) to verify the accuracy of franchise fees paid city. All records reasonably necessary for such audit will be made available by grantee at a location in or near city or at the city's option at such other locations as is convenient to city or agents acting on its behalf. Any additional amount due city shall be paid within 30 days of city's submitting an invoice for such sum, and if such sum shall exceeds five percent of the total franchise fee which the audit determines should have been paid for any calendar year, grantee shall pay city's cost of auditing that calendar year as well. 
(b)  In addition to the five percent ROW access fee and the two percent gross revenue component of the PEG fee identified in section 30-7(a), the city may require a grantee to pay a pro-rata share of such additional grants as the incumbent video provider(s) may have paid or may be paying. In determining whether such additional fee shall be charged, city shall: 
(1)  Consider whether the incumbent video provider(s) currently pay or have paid consideration (in addition to the ROW access fee and the two percent PEG fee) for its franchise in the form of any of the following: 
a.  The network component of the local emergency alert system, as contemplated in section 30-10(a)(2)a. herein; 
b.  Upstream signal input points required as a component of the local emergency alert system, and contemplated by section 30-10(a)(2)b. herein; 
c.  Video distribution facilities reaching into city classrooms and other publicly-owned facilities where the public congregates, required as a component of the local emergency alert system, and contemplated by section 30-10(a)(2)c. herein; 
d.  Any other grant. 
(2)  In the event that any of the items contemplated in section 30-7(b)(1)a., b., c. or d. are paid or have been paid to the city by an incumbent video services provider(s), the city may calculate a quarterly per-subscriber fee as follows: 
a.  The city shall first determine the direct, actual costs to the incumbent video provider(s) which have been or are associated with the provision of those items identified in section 30-7(b)(1)a., b., c., and d. The city shall next 
b.  Deduct from the those costs determined pursuant to section 30-7(b)(2)a. such recoupment as the particular incumbent video provider(s) may have achieved from building such costs into its basic service rate as permitted by governing FCC rate regulation guidelines in effect from time-to-time. The city shall next 
c.  Add all values resulting from the calculation made in section 30-7(b)(2)(B) together. The city shall next 
d.  Divide the value resulting from the calculation made in section 30-7(b)(2)c. by the total number of wireline video subscribers then exiting in the city. The city shall next 
e.  Divide the value resulting from the calculation made in subsection 30-7(b)(2)d. by four. The result of any total calculation conducted pursuant to this subsection 30-7(b)(2) shall be defined as the "Quarterly Per Subscriber PEG Fee." 
(3)  All grantees other than the incumbent video service provider(s) identified by the city shall multiply the quarterly per subscriber PEG fee by the number of basic tier subscribers that grantee held as of the last day of the previous calendar quarter; the product shall be defined as the "pro-rata PEG fee." 
(4)  Each grantee which holds a uniform video services local franchise agreement shall provide such financial and other information as the city may reasonably request in order for the city to calculate the quarterly pro-rata PEG fee. Any confidential or proprietary information submitted by a grantee may be marked as such, and the city shall protect such marked information from public disclosure as may be permitted by governing law. 
(5)  Receipt of a video services local franchise agreement shall be deemed to constitute a grantee's acceptance of the city's exclusive jurisdiction to calculate any required quarterly per subscriber PEG fee. Any person accepting a video services local franchise agreement shall also be deemed to have provided a covenant that it shall not directly or indirectly challenge the quarterly per subscriber PEG fee as said fee may be calculated from time to time and charged by city. 
(6)  Any pro-rata fee charged by the city shall be paid at the same time as the other components of the video service provider fee are due, i.e., within 45 days of the end of each calendar quarter. 
(7)  After receipt of each pro-rata fee, the city shall determine whether some or all of the pro-rata fee shall be paid over to the incumbent video service provider(s) in order to reduce that provider's(') relative expense related to those items considered in section 30-7(b)(1)a.-d. In rendering such determinations, the city shall pay over to the incumbent video service provider(s) pro-rata fees collected unless the city, in its sole discretion, believes that upgrades or improvements to the local emergency alert system are desirable; in such case(s), the city may retain one or more pro-rata fee payment and utilize that payment(s) for such purposes. 
(8)  This section 30-7(b) shall be construed and implemented by the city in a manner which promotes competitive neutrality between the providers. A provider's acceptance of a franchise shall be deemed as the provider's covenant to the city that it shall not challenge the city's determinations with respect to the collection, use, or payments over to an incumbent video service provider(s) of the pro-rata fee. 
(c)  Recovery permitted. Each grantee shall be permitted to recover in the manner permitted by governing FCC rate regulations all video service provider fees which are paid to the city. 
(d)  Financial verification. Each grantee shall provide an annual, itemized statement of all revenues derived by the company and attributable to its operation of a cable system in the city, together with an itemized statement of expenses attributable to the grantee's operation in the city. Said revenue and expense statements shall be itemized in the manner in which grantee ordinarily keeps its ledger of accounts and each statement shall be audited and certified by a nationally-recognized independent accounting firm. The aforesaid financial verification shall be due by May 1 of each year for the prior year. 
(e)  Permit fees. Each grantee shall pay the following permit and inspection fees in a manner consistent with Municipal Code: 
(1)  Permit fees shall be paid in accordance with the city's Code for any construction by grantee. 
(2)  Grantee shall pay the reasonable cost of municipal inspections for permitted construction and any reasonable "out of pocket" expenses of the city which result from inspections or street openings by grantee. 
(3)  Fees customarily charged or reasonably incurred by the city for reviews of preliminary or final engineering plans and specifications of the cable system; provided however, to the extent the city finds it necessary to hire a specialized independent engineering firm for the resolution of non-routing, highly technical, and unforeseen problems particular to the video industry, it shall so advise grantee, and grantee agrees to reimburse city for reasonable expenses incurred by such firm. 
(f)  Interest if late. All sums not paid when due shall bear interest at a rate which is one percent over the prime rate then being charged by Comerica Bank, and computed monthly. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-8. - Modification of franchise. 
(a)  Modification of franchise requirements. Subject to governing law, a grantee may obtain from the city modifications of its franchise as follows: 
(1)  Facilities, equipment. In the case of any requirement for facilities or equipment, including public, educational, or governmental access facilities or equipment, if grantee demonstrates that it is commercially impracticable for grantee to comply with such requirement, and the proposal by grantee for modification of such requirement is appropriate because of commercial impracticability. 
(2)  Service. In the case of any requirement for customer service, if grantee demonstrates that it is commercially impracticable for grantee to comply with such requirement, and the proposal by grantee for modification of such requirement is appropriate because of commercial impracticability. 
(b)  Public proceeding. Any final decision by the city under this section shall be made in a public proceeding. Such decision shall be made within 120 days after receipt of such request by the city, unless such 120-day period is extended by mutual agreement of grantee and the city. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-9. - Cable channels for educational or governmental use. 
(a)  Exclusive educational and governmental access channels. Each grantee shall make available two channels for use of the city or its designee. The required channels shall not be used for a commercial purpose, or in a manner that competes directly or indirectly with any service or offering of a grantee. 
(b)  Editorial control. A grantee shall not exercise any editorial control over any educational or governmental use of channel capacity provided pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-10. - System design and public safety. 
(a)  With respect to emergency alert systems, each grantee shall: 
(1)  Install as a part of its cable system, and shall operate throughout the term hereof, an emergency alert system (EAS) or successor to that system in accordance with all requirements imposed from time to time by the FCC. In establishing its EAS system, grantee shall, in accordance with FCC or other applicable regulations, cooperate with city on the use and operation by city of the emergency alert system. 
(2)  Install as part of their cable systems, and shall operate throughout the term of its particular franchise a local emergency alert system which shall permit the city manager, city police chief or city fire chief and his or her designates to override the audio feed to all video programming with an emergency message generated by an authorized city official and/or to distribute an emergency video message over a government access channel. The local emergency alert system shall be designed such that said local emergency messages are distributed to subscribers within the city's limits only, and shall be comprised of the following components: 
a.  A private, secure network constructed by grantee which connects each public facility within the city identified on exhibit 2, following this article (including, without limitation, all administrative buildings, police and fire stations) and which provides the capability of delivering confidential data, video and voice communications between city facilities in the event of an emergency. Such network shall incorporate the following features: 
i.  System topology that is transparent (i.e., usable) to any future electronics system; 
ii.  A backbone system that is capable of carrying traffic from the main hub to intermediate hubs in a physical ring topology; 
iii.  A cabling network that will provide service in the 20-year range, utilizing single-mode fiber; and 
iv.  All cable when entering a building will terminate within 50 feet, or transfer to metallic conduit or rated duct in order to meet fire codes, as designated by city. All fiber shall terminate with SC optical connectors. 
b.  An upstream path from the Saline municipal building, 100 North Harris Street, and further provide necessary electronic equipment such that the city has the capability of delivering emergency video messages produced by the city to the headend of a grantee. 
c.  A distribution network and necessary electronic components capable of delivering the city produced emergency audio and/or video message into the home of each of grantee's subscribers and into each public classroom within the public school district and such other buildings which are publicly-owned and designated by the city. 
d.  If a location contemplated by section 30-10(a)(2)a., b., or c. is relocated, then grantee shall relocate the contemplated local emergency alert system capabilities to that new location if: 
1.  The new location is within 300 feet; and 
2.  If grantee has an opportunity to "pre-wire" the new location during the new location's construction. 
If the new location does not meet with the two requirements listed in the immediately preceding sentence, then grantee shall relocate the service drop to the new location upon city's request and upon payment to the grantee of the grantee's direct, actual cost of relocating the facility. 
(b)  The city shall have an indefeasible right to use those portions of the system identified in subsections 30-10(a)(2)a., b. and c. in any manner determined by the city in its sole discretion. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the requirement contained in section 10-30(a)(2)a., b., and c., the city shall not require that a pre-existing local emergency alert system be duplicated by a second and subsequent grantees. Instead, city shall require a second and subsequent grantees to contribute to such facilities on a pro-rata basis through a "pro-rata fee," as contemplated by section 30-7(b) herein. 
(d)  All construction related to the local emergency alert system shall be completed not later than 18 months after grantee accepts a uniform video services local franchise agreement. The local emergency alert system shall be maintained by grantees and subject to testing by city at monthly intervals. 
(e)  Standby power supplies. Grantee shall provide backup or standby electric power (such as from batteries or from electric generators) at all locations on its cable system where the loss of electric power might disrupt the delivery of emergency messages within the city such that the system will operate for at least two hours even if electric service from conventional utility lines is interrupted. Notwithstanding the above, a grantee shall not be required to install standby power in locations where the electrical supply to the cable power supply location is the same as that which provides electrical power to the majority of homes served by the cable power supply. 
(f)  Each grantee may recoup its proportionate actual and direct cost associated with the construction and maintenance of the local emergency alert system in the manner permitted under governing law. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-11. - Signal quality requirements and public safety. 
(a)  FCC requirements. Grantee shall comply with all valid rules and regulations of the FCC with respect to the reception, carriage, and distribution of signals. 
(b)  Testing by grantee. Each grantee shall provide the city upon request with a report of testing for compliance with such rules and regulations, which shall be done in full compliance with the FCC rules and regulations. Such report shall state, in pertinent part, that the person doing the testing has been provided a copy of and reviewed the applicable regulations of the FCC. Such report shall set forth with specificity and in detail all areas of non-compliance, their actual or likely scope and causes, and grantee's recommendation of the best corrective measures to immediately and permanently correct the non-compliance. 
(c)  Testing by the city. The city at its expense may test grantee's cable system for compliance with the FCC technical standards once per year upon 15-day prior notice to grantee. 
(d)  Subscriber complaints. Unless a different process was established and noticed to subscribers prior to January 1, 2007, each grantee shall establish the following procedure for resolving complaints from subscribers about the quality of the video services delivered to them: All complaints shall go initially to grantee's office. All matters not resolved by grantee shall at grantee's or the subscriber's option be referred to the city for it to resolve. All matters not resolved by the city shall be referred to the Michigan Public Service Commission for it to resolve. Each grantee shall annually notify its subscribers of the preceding. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-12. - Construction and rights-of-way and public safety. 
(a)  Erection, removal, and common use of poles. No poles or other wire holding structures shall be erected by a grantee without prior approval of the city with regard to location, height, type, and other pertinent aspect. The city shall not unreasonably deny approval. However, no location of any pole or wire holding structure of grantee shall be a vested interest and such pole and structure shall be removed or modified by grantee at its expense whenever the city determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. Where the city or a public utility serving the city desires to make use of the poles or other wire holding structures of grantee, but agreement therefor with the grantee cannot be reached, the city may require grantee to permit such use for such consideration and upon such terms as the council shall determine to be just and reasonable, if the council determines that the use would enhance the public convenience and would not unduly interfere with grantee's operation. 
(b)  Underground locations. In those areas of the city where transmission or distribution facilities of both the current public utility providing telephone service and the utility providing electric service are underground or hereafter may be placed underground, then each grantee shall likewise construct, operate and maintain all of its transmission and distribution facilities underground to the maximum extent that then existing technology permits, and in conformance with the then existing National Electrical Safety Code as well as in conformance with all applicable state and local ordinances and codes. In the event of a grantee having to reconstruct its facilities underground, grantee will be afforded compensation if the other utilities are afforded compensation for reconstructing their facilities underground. If and when necessary, amplifiers and/or transformers in the grantee's transmission and distribution lines may be located in appropriate housings upon the surface of the ground. 
(c)  Rights-of-way. In using public rights-of-ways, each grantee shall ensure the following: 
(1)  Safety, appearance. The safety, functioning and appearance of the property and the convenience and safety of other persons shall not be adversely affected by the installation, maintenance, or construction of facilities necessary for the cable system. 
(2)  Distribution of expense. The cost of the installation, construction, operation, maintenance, or removal of such facilities shall be borne by grantee or its subscribers, or a combination of both. 
(3)  Just compensation. The owner of the property shall be justly compensated by grantee for actual damages caused by the installation, construction, operation, maintenance, or removal of such by the grantee. 
(4)  Minimum interference. All transmission and distribution structures, lines, and equipment erected by grantee, within the city, shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, alleys, and other public ways and public places, and to cause minimum interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of the said streets, alleys, or public ways and public places. 
(5)  Damage to public property. In case of disturbances of any street, sidewalk, alley, public way, or paved area, grantee shall, at its own cost and in a manner approved by the council or its representative(s), replace and restore such street, sidewalk, alley, public way or paved area in as reasonably a good a condition as existed prior to such disturbance. 
(6)  Relocation of equipment and materials. If at any time during the period of this franchise, the city shall lawfully elect to alter or change the grade of any street, sidewalk, alley, or other public way, grantee, upon reasonable notice by the city, shall remove or relocate its poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes, and other fixtures at its own expense. 
(7)  Interference with travel. Any poles or other fixtures placed in any public way by grantee shall be placed in such a manner so as not to endanger persons or property and so as not to interfere with the usual travel on such public way. 
(8)  Engineering standards, FCC specifications. All of grantee's plant and equipment, including but not limited to the antenna site, head-ends and distribution system, towers, house connections, structures, poles, wires, cables, coaxial cables, fixtures, and appurtenances shall be installed, located, erected, constructed, reconstructed, replaced, removed, repaired, maintained, and operated in accordance with good engineering practices and meet all relevant specifications of the FCC and federal law, or, where not regulated by federal law, state and local law. 
(9)  Rights of permit holders. Each grantee shall, at the request of any private party holding an appropriate permit issued by the city, temporarily raise or lower its lines to permit the moving of any building or other structure, and the actual expense of such shall be paid by the party so requesting. Grantee may require that such expense be paid prior to its raising or lowering its lines. 
(d)  Construction-City permits. For purposes of this subsection, "construction" shall not include any standard "new-customer hook-up" by grantee, provided that extraordinary installations requiring structural modifications to the customer's premises shall constitute "construction." 
(1)  Prior to the commencement of construction, grantee shall apply for and obtain all city permits required of grantee by the City Code, including but not limited to building permits, street-cut permits, etc., and shall comply with all terms of such permits. Grantee where practicable shall utilize existing poles in the city. It is the stated intention of the city that all holders of franchises and rights within the corporate limits of the city will cooperate with the video provider's usage of their poles and pole line facilities whenever possible so that the number of new or additional pole line facilities installed within the city may be minimized. 
(2)  Supervision of construction; inspection. Without, in any way, limiting the provisions of subsection 30-12(d) the city, through its appropriately designated officials and representatives, shall have the right to inspect all construction or installation work performed within the public rights-of-way, streets and other easements dedicated for compatible uses as it shall find necessary to insure compliance with the requirements of this chapter, the City Code, applicable permits, and other pertinent provisions of law. Such inspections shall be performed in a timely and expeditious manner. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-13. - Customer service and the transaction of local business. 
(a)  Effective, prompt service. Grantee shall render effective service, make repairs promptly and interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions, insofar as is possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum use of the system. 
(b)  No discrimination. No grantee shall deny service, deny access, or otherwise discriminate on the availability or rates, terms or conditions of cable services provided to actual or potential subscribers on the basis of race, color, creed, religion, ancestry, national origin, sex, disability, age, marital status, location within city, status with regard to public assistance, income level, or other demographics. All grantees shall comply at all times with all applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations relating to nondiscrimination. 
(c)  All grantees shall comply with 47 C.F.R. §76.309(c) and the associated FCC Order which implemented said section (Report & Order, In the Matter of Implementation of Section 8 of the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 , FCC 93-145 (Released April 7, 1993) as each currently exist and may from time-to-time be amended. The city reserves the right by ordinance and subject to applicable law to alter or amend the customer service and consumer protection matters set forth in this part. 
(1)  All grantees shall have a local or toll-free telephone number available for use by subscribers toll-free 24 hours per day, seven days per week. 
(2)  A grantee's numbers shall be listed, with appropriate explanations, in the directory published by the local telephone company or companies and shall be printed on each grantee's bills to customers. 
(3)  Trained company representatives will be available to respond to subscriber telephone inquiries during normal business hours. Any calls answered after normal business hours shall be responded to by a trained company representative on the next business day. 
(4)  Under normal operating conditions, telephone answer time by a customer representative, including wait time, shall not exceed 30 seconds from when the connection is made. If the call needs to be transferred, transfer time shall not exceed 30 seconds. These standards shall be met no less than 90 percent of the time under normal operating conditions, measured on a quarterly basis. 
(5)  Under normal operating conditions, the subscriber will not receive a busy signal more than three percent of the time. 
(d)  Subject to applicable law, each grantee shall provide reports to City quarterly upon request as follows. 
(1)  The reports shall be in a form acceptable to the city, showing on a consistent basis, fairly applied the matters set forth below so as to measure grantee's compliance with the standards of the referenced sections. Such reports shall show grantee's performance excluding periods of abnormal operating conditions, and if grantee contends any such conditions occurred during the period in questions, it shall also describe the nature and extent of conditions and show grantee's performance both including and excluding the time periods grantee contends such conditions were in effect. 
(2)  The reports shall show the number of phone calls originating from within the city (or other appropriate area) and measure grantee's compliance with the standards of subsections 30-13(c)(4) and (5). They shall also measure and report on grantee's compliance with subsections 30-13(f)(2) and (3). 
(e)  A customer service center and bill payment locations will be open at least during normal business hours and will be conveniently located within the county. 
(f)  With respect to service interruptions: 
(1)  Under normal operating conditions, each grantee will meet the standards of subsections 30-13(f)(2) and (3) no less than 95 percent of the time measured on a quarterly basis. 
(2)  Excluding conditions beyond a grantee's control, grantee will begin working on a service interruption promptly and in no event later than 24 hours after the interruption becomes known to grantee. 
(3)  Excluding conditions beyond a grantee's control, grantee will begin working on subscriber complaints involving impairment or degradation of signal quality (other than a service interruption) on the next business day after notification of the service problem. 
(g)  The "appointment window" alternatives for installations, service calls, and other installation activities will be either a specific time or, at maximum, a four-hour time block during normal business hours. The operator may schedule service calls and other installation activities outside of normal business hours for the express convenience of the customer. 
(1)  An operator may not cancel an appointment with a customer after the close of business on the business day prior to the scheduled appointment. 
(2)  If a provider's representative is running late for an appointment with a customer and will not be able to keep the appointment as scheduled, the customer will be contacted. The appointment will be rescheduled, as necessary, at a time which is convenient for the customer. 
(h)  Under normal operating conditions, installations located up to 125 aerial feet from the existing distribution cable system will be performed within seven business days after an order has been placed no less than 95 percent of the time, measured on a quarterly basis. Unless otherwise expressly permitted by governing law, no line extension charge or comparable charge shall be imposed on any current or potential subscriber for "standard drops" of 125 feet or less from the distribution portion or tap on the cable system to the subscriber's premises. 
(i)  A video service provider shall not do in connection with the providing of video service to its subscribers any of the following: 
(1)  Make a statement or representation, including the omission of material information, regarding the rates, terms, or conditions of providing video service that is false, misleading, or deceptive. As used in this subdivision, "material information" includes, but is not limited to, all applicable fees, taxes, and charges that will be billed to the subscriber, regardless of whether the fees, taxes, or charges are authorized by state or federal law. 
(2)  Charge a customer for a subscribed service for which the customer did not make an initial affirmative order. Failure to refuse an offered or proposed subscribed service is not an affirmative order for the service. 
(3)  If a customer has terminated a service, charge the customer for service provided after the effective date the service was canceled. 
(4)  Cause a probability of confusion or a misunderstanding as to the legal rights, obligations, or remedies of a party to a transaction by making a false, deceptive or misleading statement or by failing to inform the customer of a material fact, the omission of which is deceptive or misleading. 
(5)  Represent or imply that the subject of a transaction will be provided promptly, or at a specified time, or within a reasonable time, if the provider knows or has reason to know that it will not be so provided. 
(6)  Enter into a transaction in which the subscriber waives or purports to waive a right, benefit, or immunity provided by law, unless the waiver is clearly stated and the consumer has specifically consented to it. 
(7)  To the extent not already contemplated in the immediately-preceding subsections 30-13(i)(1)-(6), provider shall comply with all applicable provisions of the Michigan Consumers Protection Act, 1976 PA 331. 
(j)  All service personnel of each grantee and its contractors or subcontractors who have as part of their normal duties contact with the general public shall wear clothing with grantee's name and logo clearly visible on the front and back of their clothing and shall have an identification card bearing their name and photograph. Grantee shall account for all identification cards at all times. Every service vehicle of a grantee, its contractors and subcontractors shall be clearly identified as such to the public: grantee's vehicles shall have grantee's logo and phone number plainly visible; those of contractors and subcontractors working for grantee shall have the contractor's/subcontractor's name and phone number plus markings (such as magnetic door sign) indicating they are under contract to grantee and grantee's telephone number. 
(k)  Late payment. Late payment charges shall be assessed only in accordance with this subsection and shall be not more than $5.00; provided however, that grantee may increase such limit for inflation if the new amount bears a reasonable resemblance to the cost of maintaining and collecting the delinquent accout. No late charge shall be assessed before the thirty-fifth day subsequent to the day on which the bill was mailed to the subscriber. 
(l)  Disconnection. 
(1)  Grantee may only disconnect a subscriber for failure to pay if at least 45 days have elapsed after the due date for payment of the subscriber's bill and grantee has provided at least 10 days written notice to the subscriber prior to disconnection, and a follow-up written notice or telephone call specifying the effective date after which cable services are subject to disconnection. 
(2)  At any time grantee in good faith believes that the subscriber has tampered with or abused grantee's equipment, that there is a signal leakage problem (or other non-compliance with FCC rules or other standards which poses a risk to lives or property) on subscriber's premises, or that subscriber is or may be engaged in the theft of cable services, grantees' remedies shall include disconnecting the subscriber. 
(3)  Notice. Each grantee shall promptly disconnect any subscriber who so requests disconnection. Unless otherwise stated by the subscriber, the disconnection date shall be considered that date when grantee receives the disconnect request. No charge may be imposed upon the subscriber for any cable service delivered after the disconnection date. 
(m)  Privacy and monitoring. Grantee shall not use its cable system to collect personally identifiable information concerning any subscriber without the prior written or electronic consent of the subscriber concerned; provided, however, that a grantee may use the cable system to collect such information in order to obtain information necessary to render a cable service or other service provided by grantee to the subscriber or to detect unauthorized reception of cable communications. 
(n)  Minimized disruption. Grantee shall avoid planned and intentional service outages to the greatest possible extent and, when such outages must occur, shall schedule them to the extent possible during periods of minimum use of the system. Where service outages extend for more than 24 hours, grantee shall credit subscribers on a pro rata basis for services not received during the period of service outage which occurs after grantee is notified by the subscriber of such outage, provided however, that no credit shall be provided for outages caused by the subscriber. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-14. - Financial safeguards and the protection of public assets. 
(a)  Insurance. 
(1)  During the term of its franchise, grantee shall maintain, or cause to be maintained, in full force and effect and at its sole cost and expense, the following types and limits of insurance: 
a.  Workers compensation insurance meeting state statutory requirements and employer's liability insurance with minimum limits of $100,000.00 for each accident. 
b.  Comprehensive commercial general liability insurance with minimum limits of $5,000,000.00 as the combined single limit for each occurrence of bodily injury, personal injury and property damage. The policy shall provide blanket contractual liability insurance for all written contracts, and shall include coverage for products and completed operations liability, independent contractor's liability; coverage for property damage from perils of explosion, collapse or damage to underground utilities, commonly known as XCU coverage. 
c.  Automobile liability insurance covering all owned, hired, and non-owned vehicles in use by grantee, its employees and agents, with personal protection insurance and property protection insurance to comply with the provisions of the state no-fault insurance law, including residual liability insurance with minimum limits of $5,000,000.00 as the combined single limit for each occurrence for bodily injury and property damage. 
d.  At the start of and during the period of any construction, builders all-risk insurance providing coverage on all building and structures which will be installed or constructed as part of the cable system together with an installation floater or equivalent property coverage covering cables, materials, machinery and supplies of any nature whatsoever which are to be used in or incidental to the construction of the cable system. Upon completion of the construction of the cable system, grantee shall substitute for the foregoing insurance policies of fire, extended coverage and vandalism and malicious mischief insurance on the entire cable system. The amount of insurance at all times shall be representative of the insurable values installed or constructed. 
(2)  All policies other than those for worker's compensation shall be written on an occurrence and not on a claims made basis. 
(3)  The coverage amounts set forth above may be met by a combination of underlying and umbrella policies so long as in combination the limits equal or exceed those stated. 
(4)  All policies, except for business interruption and worker's compensation policies, shall name the city, a municipal corporation of the state, all associated, affiliated, allied and subsidiary entities of the municipality now existing or hereafter created, and its respective officers, boards, commission, employees, agents and contractors, as their respective interests may appear as additional insureds (herein referred to as the "additional insureds"). Each policy is to be endorsed to add the additional insureds and shall contain cross-liability wording, as follows: 
"To any claim made or 'suit' brought against any one insured by another insured the coverage shall apply in the same manner and to the same extent as though a separate policy had been issued to each insured. Any breach of a condition of this policy by any insured shall not affect the protection provided by this policy to another insured." 
(5)  Evidence of insurance. Certificates of insurance for each insurance policy required to be obtained by grantee in compliance with this section, along with written evidence of payment of required premiums shall be filed and maintained with the city prior to the start of any franchise and annual during the term of the franchise. 
(6)  Cancellation of policies of insurance. All insurance policies maintained pursuant to this franchise shall contain the following endorsement: 
"At least sixty (60) days prior written notice shall be given to the city by the insurer of any intention not to renew such policy or to cancel, replace or materially alter same, such notice to be given by registered mail to City." 
(7)  Insurance companies. All insurance shall be affected under valid and enforceable policies, issued by insurers licensed to do business by the state or surplus line carriers on the state insurance commissioner's approved list of companies qualified to do business in the state. All insurance carriers and surplus line carriers shall be rated A+ or better by A.M. Best Company. 
(8)  Deductibles. All insurance policies may be written with deductibles, not to exceed $50,000.00 unless approved in advance by the city. Grantee agrees to indemnify and save harmless the city, the indemnities and additional insureds from and against the payment of any deductible and from the payment of any premium on any insurance policy required to be furnished by this franchise. 
(b)  Indemnification. Grantee shall indemnify, defend and hold the city harmless from any and all liability arising out of its franchise resulting from the acts or omissions of grantee, its assigns, employees, agents, invitees, or other persons for whom grantee is legally responsible, including, but not limited to, damages to persons or property arising out of the construction, maintenance or operation of the cable system, infringement of civil rights, patents, trademarks, trade names, or copy rights, libel, or slander. Grantee shall reimburse the city for its reasonable actual expenses incurred to defend against any such action to include, but not be limited to, attorney fees, expert witness fees, discovery expenses, court fees, damages and penalties and interest thereon, and expense incurred on appeal. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-15. - Maps, plats, and reports. 
(a)  Records retained. Grantee shall maintain copies of the following records and reports for at least a three-year period: Signal leakage tests, insurance policies, periodic gross revenue statements, revenue information necessary to document grantee's gross receipt statements for franchise fee purposes, customer service log reports, preventative maintenance reports, and any other applicable records and information that may be required by any other federal or state agency having jurisdiction over the grantee. 
(b)  Inspection of records. The city shall have the right to review at a mutually agreeable location all records and reports identified in this section and any other record or report related to grantee's transaction of business within the city on ten days' written notice. Such review, unless mutually agreed upon or judicially ordered, should occur within grantee's normal business hours. Moreover, the city will only request financial records on an as needed basis and will treat such information as confidential and proprietary to the fullest extent allowed by the state and federal law. 
(c)  Location of facilities/miss dig. Grantee shall provide the city upon request copies of any new "as-built" or comparable drawings as they are generated for portions of grantee's facilities and cable system located within the city. Upon request by the city, grantee shall mark up maps provided by the city so as to show the location of grantee's facilities and cable system. Each grantee shall participate in and be a member of the "Miss Dig" utility notification program provided for by MCL § 460.701ff or subsequent statute. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-16. - Rights reserved to the city. 
(a)  Generally-Applicable and cable service regulations. Each grantee shall, at all times during the period of a franchise granted hereunder, be subject to such reasonable regulations, generally-applicable to all commercial businesses operating in the city, as the city shall hereinafter provide. Grantee shall further be subject to and comply with all federal law and regulations related to its business, including, without limitation, those contained in the cable act and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(b)  Supervision, inspection. The city shall have the right to supervise all construction or installation work performed in the public rights-of-way and make such inspections, audits, or reviews of grantee's business records as city shall find necessary to insure compliance with this chapter and all other pertinent provisions of law. At the expiration, termination or cancellation of a franchise, the city shall have the right to require the grantee to remove at its own expense all portions of the cable communications system from all public streets, alleys, ways, and areas within the city. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-17. - Suspension of requirements. 
    The city may suspend any provision of this chapter which imposes an obligation on grantees, in whole or in part, for any length of time; provided, however, that any such waiver must: 
(1)  First be approved by resolution of the city council; and 
(2)  Be in writing and indicate with specificity the provision waived and the duration of such suspension; and 
(3)  Be applied on a competitively-neutral basis to all grantees. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-18. - Remedies. 
    For any violation of this chapter, the city shall be entitled to any and all of the following cumulative remedies: 
(1)  The commencement of an action at law for monetary damages. 
(2)  The commencement of an action of equity seeking injunctive or declaratory relief or the specific performance of any of the provisions which, as a matter of equity, are specifically enforceable. 
(3)  Revocation of: 
a.  Any consent previously given by the city to utilize the city's streets and rights-of-way to provide utility service, as provided pursuant to section 30-5(b)(1); and/or 
b.  The right to utilize city rights-of-way to transact business within the city, as otherwise provided pursuant to section 30-5(b)(2). 
(4)  Issuance of a municipal civil infraction citation, with civil fines and penalties not to exceed $500.00, 90 days in jail, or both. Continuing violations shall be deemed to create a separate civil infraction for each day on which the violation continues to exist. 
(5)  Grantee shall reimburse reasonable attorney fees and other costs incurred by city which arise as a result of city's efforts to enforce grantee's compliance with this chapter. Such fees and costs shall be included as a component of any judgment, order or other relief granted to the city pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07) 
Sec. 30-19. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Access. Subject to the provisions of this chapter, city shall allow all grantees to install, construct, and maintain a video service network within the public rights-of-way and shall provide each grantee with open, comparable, non-discriminatory and competitively neutral access to the public rights-of-way. The city shall not discriminate against a grantee to provide video service for any of the following: 
(1)  The authorization or placement of a video service network in the public rights-of-way; 
(2)  Access to a building owned by a governmental entity; 
(3)  A municipal utility pole. 
(b)  No relationship. To the extent that ay relationship is deemed to exist between the city and a grantee other than that of franchisor and franchisee, such relationship shall be considered an independent contractual relationship, and no liability or benefits, such as worker's compensation, pension rights or liabilities, insurance rights or liabilities or other provisions or liabilities, arising out of or related to a contract for hire or employer/employee relationship, shall arise or accrue to either party or to either party's agents or employees as a result of grantee holding a franchise. 
(c)  Captions. Captions or headings to sections or subsections thereof are intended to provide ready access to this chapter and shall not be construed in any manner to interpret the content of any section or subsection thereof. 
(d)  Severability. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. If such disclosure is subsequently repealed, rescinded, amended or otherwise changed, so that the provision which had been declared invalid is no longer so, said section, clause or paragraph shall thereupon return to full force and effect and shall thereafter be enforceable, provided that the city shall give the grantees 30 days written notice of such change before requiring compliance with this article. 
(e)  Conflict. In the event of a conflict between this article and the provisions of any franchise issued to a video service provider, the terms most benefiting the health, safety, and general public welfare of the residents of the city shall control, as determined by the city. 
(f)  Federal law. Any and all provisions of this chapter shall be interpreted in accordance with and subject to governing and enforceable federal and state law. 
(Ord. No. 705, 5-7-07)
