    Authorized city officials including, but not limited to, police officers, city code enforcement officers, city building inspectors, volunteers trained pursuant to MCL 257.675d, or corresponding successor statute, and any other trained city personnel authorized by the city manager, may authorize and serve parking violation notices and citations under this Code. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-8. - Responsibility for violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is the driver, owner or person in charge of or control over a motor vehicle to permit said motor vehicle to remain or to be placed or to place such vehicle in any parking zone where any sign, device, or other notice of parking limitation installed pursuant to this chapter is displaying a sign or signal showing that such motor vehicle shall have already parked beyond the period of time fixed by the city council for such parking zone, or be parked for longer than the maximum time indicated or in violation of any parking rule or regulation set forth pursuant to this chapter or adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-9. - Penalties. 
(a)  The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code are adopted by reference; provided, however, that the city may not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than 93 days, provided, however, that a violation of MCL 257.625(1)(C) is punishable by one or more of the following: 
(1)  Community service of not more than 360 hours; 
(2)  Imprisonment for not more than 180 days; and 
(3)  A fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $700.00. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this chapter not designated under the Michigan Vehicle Code is a civil infraction, unless otherwise designated by this Code. 
(c)  Parking violation notice and citation penalties shall be paid in accordance with the schedule of fines set by resolution of the city council. If a citation has been issued for a violation, a parking violation notice may no longer be paid at the parking violations bureau. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-10. - Impoundment. 
(a)  A vehicle parked in violation of this chapter, including but not limited to a vehicle with six or more unpaid parking violation notices or citations, or in any other circumstance in which impoundment is authorized under the Michigan Vehicle Code, including but not limited to section 252d, is hereby declared to be a nuisance which may be abated by any police officer or other authorized city official in either of the following ways: 
(1)  By placing a parking violation notice or citation tag on said vehicle which shall plainly state the nature of the violation; or 
(2)  By placing a parking violation notice or citation tag on such vehicle as in the preceding paragraph, and by removing or causing said vehicle to be removed to the vehicle pound in accordance with the procedures for impoundment authorized under the Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(b)  Whenever a parking violation notice or citation tag is placed on a vehicle, a copy of such tag shall be transmitted to the parking violations bureau where a file record shall be made and kept of said violation. 
(c)  The owner or operator of any vehicle upon which a parking violation notice or citation tag has been placed and which has been removed to the vehicle pound may have said vehicle released by paying all violation charges at the parking violations bureau which are due against said vehicle and paying all costs of impoundment to the towing contractor of the city, however the total amount required for the owner or operator to obtain release of the vehicle shall not exceed $500.00 pending final adjudication of the case. Following final adjudication of the case, the owner or operator of the vehicle may be responsible for any additional unpaid violation charges and costs of impoundment. 
(d)  Any lienholder may claim an impounded vehicle by entering into an indemnity agreement with the city to save harmless the city from any and all liability the city may incur at the hands of the registered owner for releasing said vehicle to said lienholder, and upon all charges due against said vehicle. The aforementioned charges shall include, but not be limited to, all parking violation penalties presently outstanding against the vehicle, and all levies and costs of towing and storage and other impoundment expenses. 
(e)  Whenever a parking violation tag has been placed on a vehicle and where the necessary steps have been taken to have said vehicle removed but is released to the owner or operator thereof prior to such actual removal, the owner or operator thereof shall pay to the towing contractor of the city all costs and expenses by reason of the institution of those steps necessary for removal of the vehicle. The towing contractor of the city may release the vehicle without removal as above mentioned by accepting payment of all costs and expenses to which he or she would be entitled for removal of the vehicle, however such amount shall not exceed $500.00. 
(f)  Whenever any person authorized by this Code to enforce this chapter shall determine that a vehicle parking in violation of this chapter shall be ticketed with a parking violation tag and removed to the vehicle pound, as provided, it shall thereafter be unlawful for any person to drive or otherwise remove said vehicle from the scene of the violation in disobedience of a direct verbal order given by such authorized person that the vehicle not be moved. This provision, however, shall not prohibit the towing contractor of the city from removing such vehicle as authorized by this section. A vehicle which has been impounded shall not be removed from the vehicle pound except as authorized by the city. 
(g)  All fine(s) shall be paid as set forth in section 86-9. All costs of impoundment shall be paid directly to the towing contractor of the city. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Secs. 86-11-86-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING METERS AND DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 787 , § 1, adopted Sept. 19, 2016, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 86-26-86-30, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to vehicle code and derived from Code 1968, § 19-4; Ord. No. 361, § 5, adopted June 15, 1981; Ord. No. 374, § 2, adopted March 14, 1983; Ord. No. 389, § 1, adopted Aug. 6, 1984; Ord. No. 396, § 1, adopted Jan. 13, 1986; Ord. No. 492, § 1, adopted Dec. 16, 1991; Ord. No. 580, § 1, adopted May 19, 1997; Ord. No. Ord. No. 622, §§ 1-5, adopted Feb. 28, 2000; and Ord. No. 728, § 1, adopted June 7, 2010. 

Sec. 86-26. - Parking meters and other devices authorized. 
(a)  Wherever by reason of traffic congestion or other cause, the public safety is imperiled, the convenience of the public cannot be served, the traffic regulations cannot be adequately enforced without the assistance to be obtained through the installation and maintenance of parking meters or other parking devices (collectively "parking devices"), or traffic conditions in any particular location or any particular street seem to require the aid of such parking devices, such devices may be installed under and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The city council may by resolution fix the fees to be charged for parking of motor vehicles in any place where such devices are placed and for any period of time, anything herein to the contrary notwithstanding. 
(c)  The coins or other form of payment required to be deposited in the parking devices as provided in this article are levied under police authority as a regulation of city traffic, and for the purpose of paying inspection fees to cover the cost of city regulation and inspection of the motor vehicles referred to in this chapter occupying the streets, and the fees shall be sufficient, when fixed by the city, for the operation, installation, control and use of the parking zones. 
(d)  No person shall park a motor vehicle in violation of such limitation, restriction or prohibition contained in this article. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-27. - Installation and maintenance of parking devices. 
(a)  The city council may by resolution authorize and require the installation of parking devices and designate the location and fix the time that parking is permitted. 
(b)  The city shall maintain the meters and devices in good working condition. 
(c)  Notice of parking reservation and the limited parking permitted shall be given by the police department by paint of distinguishing color and/or signs or devices of uniform character indicating the distances, place and space. The police department shall also provide for the erection of uniform and suitable signs or the painting of curbs, giving notice thereon of the parking reservations and the limited parking permitted. 
(d)  Each motor vehicle parked alongside of such parking device shall park within the lines or marks as are established. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle across any such line or mark, or to park the vehicle in such way that the same shall not be fully within the area so designated by such lines or markings. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-28. - Display of signal; overtime parking prohibited. 
(a)  Each parking device shall be so set as to display a signal showing legal parking upon the deposit of a coin, money of the United States, or other form of payment designated on the parking device, therein for a period of time conforming to the parking limit set out in appropriate resolutions passed by the city council for that part of the street upon which the devices are placed. 
(b)  Each parking device shall also be so arranged that upon the expiration of the parking time limit, it will indicate by a mechanically or digitally operated signal that the lawful parking period as fixed by the resolution has expired, and in such cases, the right of the motor vehicle to occupy such space shall cease and the driver, possessor, or person having control thereof, shall be subject to the penalties hereinafter provided. 
(c)  Parking meters or devices, when installed, shall be placed upon the curb or sidewalk alongside of or next to parking device zones to be designated as hereinafter provided. 
(e)  Each parking device shall be so set as to show or display a signal that the parking space alongside the same is or is not lawfully occupied. 
(f)  The owner, operator, one having control of, or driver of the motor vehicle shall upon entering the parking device zone immediately deposit a coin, United States money, in the parking device alongside of or next to the parking device zone, and the parking device zone may then be used by the motor vehicle, and the driver, owner, possessor or one having control thereof, during the time of the parking limit, as provided for by the resolution of the city council for that part of the street in which the parking device zone is limited. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any driver, owner, possessor or one having control thereof of any motor vehicle to allow such vehicle to remain parked in any such parking device zone beyond the parking time limit as fixed by resolution of the city council for such zone, or after the parking device meter has expired and the same shall constitute a violation of this chapter, subject to the penalties provided herein. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit in any parking device a coin or other payment for the purpose of extending the parking time beyond a time fixed by the resolution of the city council for parking in the zone alongside of, or next to which the parking device is placed, unless such person shall be the agent or associate of the owner or driver or manager of the car. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-29. - Days, hours limits effective. 
(a)  The parking time limit as herein provided for shall apply from 8:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m. of each Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday; provided however, that there shall be no parking time limit during Sunday and the following legal holidays: 
(1)  New Year's Day; 
(2)  Memorial Day; 
(3)  Independence Day; 
(4)  Labor Day; 
(5)  Thanksgiving Day; and 
(6)  Christmas Day. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-30. - Slugs and tampering prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking device a slug or other object as a substitute for the coin of the denomination of the United States, required to operate the parking device. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person not so authorized, to deface, injure, tamper, open or to willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking device installed under the terms of this article, or aid and abet in doing same. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-31. - Loading zones. 
(a)  The city council reserves the right to establish loading zones and to omit parking devices from such loading zones, if it should find it advisable and necessary from the standpoint of safety, traffic conditions and for the conduct of business and use of property by the abutting property owner or his lessees or assigns. "Loading zone" shall be defined as the space or section of the street next to the curb which has been set aside for the exclusive use of loading or unloading persons or property. 
(b)  No vehicle may remain in a loading zone for a period of time longer than is necessary to unload or load either passengers or property, nor while the operator thereof is engaged otherwise than in the loading or unloading of the vehicle, except that a reasonable time shall be allowed to secure a receipt for delivery of property. The use of time zone space, where such parking devices have been installed for loading or unloading of property, will be permitted before the hour of 10:00 a.m. without the depositing of a coin in the parking devices of such spaces, provided that the vehicle is loaded or unloaded in a single space and in the manner hereinbefore described. The provisions for loading zones are in addition to and not in derogation of regulations now or hereafter adopted in pursuance of law. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-32. - Collections from meters; deposit, use of receipts. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city manager to designate some person to make regular collections of the funds deposited in such parking devices. It shall be the duty of such persons so designated to take out the funds, which are deposited in the devices, and to deliver the same to such person as shall be designated by the city manager to receive the same. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of such person or persons designated by the city manager to receive the funds to deposit the same with the city treasurer, who shall deposit the same to such account as shall be provided by resolution of the city council, and which fund shall be disbursed by resolution of the city council for the payment of all inspection, purchase or rental cost or other charges incurred in connection with the purchase, rental or use of such devices; to further improve traffic regulations; and to establish a fund for the purpose of acquiring real estate for parking purposes. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Secs. 86-33-86-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADDITIONAL VIOLATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 787 , § 1, adopted Sept. 19, 2016, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 86-51-86-71, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to public parking and derived from Ord. No. 128, §§ 1-13, 15, 16, adopted June 2, 1953; Ord. No. 128-1, adopted Jan. 4, 1954; Ord. No. 145, § 1, adopted March 3, 1958; Code 1968, §§ 19-16-19-36; and Ord. No. 759, § 2, adopted Nov. 17, 2014 

Sec. 86-51. - Driving a motorized vehicle on land other than hard surfaced streets, driveways, and parking areas. 
    No person shall drive a motorized vehicle, other than an official emergency vehicle, on any land in the city which is not a hard surfaced street, driveway, or parking area, without the consent of the owner of said land. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-52. - Parking on lawn extension. 
(a)  No person shall drive upon, park or stand any vehicle between the curb or curbline and the lot line nearest the street, said area being commonly known as the lawn extension, whether or not any sidewalk or curb is actually in place on such street; provided, however, that said lawn extension area may be used for parking purposes by persons who are authorized to park vehicles in said area by the owner of the abutting lot, if said owner has obtained a lawn extension parking permit from the city council. 
(b)  Such a permit shall be issued by the city council to said owner upon proper application by said owner making a satisfactory showing of the following facts: 
(1)  That there is a reasonable need for such parking for business or a public purpose; 
(2)  That no unreasonable traffic hazard will be created by such parking; and 
(3)  That no undue hardship will be suffered by the owners of neighboring lots. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-53. - Use of private driveways and parking lots restricted. 
    No person shall drive, turn around, or park a motor vehicle on the private driveway or parking lot of a business, industry, school, church, or residential dwelling unit or units, except for a purpose related to the activities and functions of the owner or occupant of said private driveway or parking lot, or unless the express consent of the owner, the occupant, or their agents, has been first obtained. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-54. - Pedestrians crossing streets. 
(a)  No pedestrian shall cross a street at a location other than at a crosswalk into which vehicle traffic is then restricted by a traffic control device unless such crossing may be done safely and without interfering with motor vehicle and bicycle traffic on that street. 
(b)  No operator of a motor vehicle or bicycle shall interfere with pedestrian or bicycle traffic in a crosswalk into which vehicle traffic is then restricted by a traffic control device. 
(c)  When traffic-control devices are not in place or are not in operation at any crosswalk marked with a "yield to pedestrian" sign, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is on the half of the roadway on which the vehicle is traveling or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger, but a pedestrian shall not suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into a path of a vehicle that is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. 
(Ord. No. 787 , § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 86-55. - Motor vehicle and motorcycle insurance required. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases when used in this section will have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Automobile insurance means that term as defined in MCL 500.2102. 
(2)  Highway means that term as defined in MCL 257.20. 
(3)  Motorcycle means a vehicle having a saddle or seat for the use of the rider, designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, which is equipped with a motor that exceeds 50 cubic centimeters piston displacement. The wheels on any attachment to the vehicle shall not be considered as wheels in contact with the ground. Motorcycle does not include a moped, as defined in MCL 257.32b. Motorcycle does not include an ORV. 
(4)  Motor vehicle means a vehicle, including a trailer, operated or designed for operation upon a public highway by power other than muscular power which has more than two wheels. Motor vehicle does not include a motorcycle or a moped, as defined in MCL 257.32b. Motor vehicle does not include a farm tractor or other implement of husbandry which is not subject to the registration requirements of the Michigan vehicle code pursuant to MCL 257.216. Motor vehicle does not include an ORV. 
(5)  Owner means any of the following: 
a.  A person renting a motor vehicle or having the use thereof, under a lease or otherwise, for a period that is greater than 30 days. 
b.  A person who holds the legal title to a vehicle, other than a person engaged in the business of leasing motor vehicles who is the lessor of a motor vehicle pursuant to a lease providing for the use of the motor vehicle by the lessee for a period that is greater than 30 days. 
c.  A person who has the immediate right of possession of a motor vehicle under an installment sale contract. 
(6)  Registrant does not include a person engaged in the business of leasing motor vehicles who is the lessor of a motor vehicle pursuant to a lease providing for the use of the motor vehicle by the lessee for a period that is greater than 30 days. 
(b)  An owner or registrant of a motor vehicle or motorcycle with respect to which security is required by MCL 500.3101, MCL 500.3102, or MCL 500.3103, may not operate the motor vehicle or motorcycle or permit it to be operated upon a public highway in the City of Saline, without having in full force and effect security complying with those sections. 
(c)  A person may not operate a motor vehicle or motorcycle upon a public highway in the City of Saline with the knowledge that the owner or registrant does not have security in full force and effect as required by MCL 500.3101, MCL 500.3102, or MCL 500.3103 for that motor vehicle or motorcycle. 
(d)  The failure of a person to produce evidence that a motor vehicle or motorcycle has in full force and effect security complying with MCL 500.3101, MCL 500.3102, or MCL 500.3103 on the date of the issuance of the citation, creates a rebuttable presumption in a prosecution that the motor vehicle or motorcycle did not have in full force and effect security complying with those sections on the date of the issuance of the citation. 
(e)  A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than $200.00 nor more than $500.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 800 , § 1, 2-12-18) 
Secs. 86-56-86-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRUCKS, COMMERCIAL VEHICLES, ETC.[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 555, adopted Aug. 21, 1995, has been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as Art. IV, §§ 86-101-86-106. 

Sec. 86-101. - Enforcement. 
(a)  All the provisions of this article [Ordinance No. 555] shall be enforced by any officer of the police department of the city; and each of them is hereby authorized to enforce all the provisions of this article. 
(b)  When any such police officer is performing his duties under this section, he shall have all the powers conferred upon peace officers by the general laws of this state, and especially all such powers conferred on officers authorized to enforce the provisions of law dealing with the weights and dimensions of trucks. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 86-102. - Size, weight and load limitations generally. 
(a)  Unless specifically declared to be a civil infraction, it is a misdemeanor for a person to drive or move or for the owner to cause or permit to be driven or moved on any street or highway in the city a vehicle or vehicles of a size, weight, or load exceeding the limitations stated in this article. 
(b)  The provisions of this article governing size, weight and load shall not apply to fire apparatus, or to implements of husbandry incidentally moved upon a highway, or to a vehicle operated under the terms of a special permit. 
(c)  Each overweight axle on a vehicle shall be a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 2, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 86-103. - Truck routes. 
    As used in this section "truck" shall mean "truck," "truck tractor," "trailer," "semi-trailer," as defined in Act 300, Public Acts of Michigan, 1949, or any combination thereof. 
(1)  The operation of any truck exceeding 22 feet in length or five tons gross weight (including operator and cargo) is prohibited upon every street in the city except upon truck routes designated as such by traffic control orders. 
(2)  Provided however, that no provision of this section shall prohibit: 
a.  The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city. 
b.  The operations of vehicles owned or operated by the city, any contractor or material provider while engaged in the repair, maintenance, or construction of streets, street improvements, or street utilities within the city. 
c.  The operation of a truck upon any officially established detour in any case where such trucks could lawfully be operated upon the street for which such detour is established. 
d.  Any truck which is taking departure from or proceeding to a destination on a prohibited street from operating on such prohibited streets as may be reasonably necessary in traveling to or from, as the case may be, the nearest street intersection on a street wherein such truck is permitted to operate. 
e.  Any truck while engaged in one or more local pickups or deliveries from using such prohibited streets as may be reasonably necessary in so doing, provided that such truck shall upon completion of the last pickup or delivery, return by the shortest route to the nearest street upon which it is permitted to operate. 
(3)  It shall be the duty of any person who shall be driving or in charge or control of any truck which may at that time be upon any street in the city upon which truck travel is limited or restricted, upon the demand of any police officer, to proceed to any public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining whether the weight thereof is in excess of the weight limit permitted upon such street. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 3, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 86-104. - Truck identification. 
    No person shall engage in commerce in the operation on the public streets of the city a motor truck, tractor, trailer or semi-trailer unless it shall have painted or otherwise lettered upon it the name of the business, the business address, the phone number of the registered owner of the vehicle and the lessee of the vehicle if the vehicle is being operated under lease. The letters of this information shall not be less than three inches in height. The information shall be conspicuously placed on the outside of the vehicle. This section shall not be applicable to trucks eligible for and equipped with farm commercial license plates. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 4, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 86-105. - Commercial vehicles; equipment and operation. 
    A motor carrier or driver shall not operate or cause or permit to be operated any vehicle in violation of Act 181 of 1963 as amended (Motor Carrier Safety Act MCL 480.11 et seq.) or rules adopted under it. The words of this section mean the same as defined within Act 181 of 1963 as amended and rules adopted under it. Any violation of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by up to a $500.00 fine and/or 90 days in jail. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 5, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 86-106. - Size, weight and load. 
    Unless specifically declared to be a civil infraction, it is a misdemeanor for a person to drive or move or for the owner to cause or permit to be driven or moved on a street or highway a vehicle or vehicles of a size or weight exceeding the limitations stated in, or otherwise in violation of, the following provisions of the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code, Act 300 of 1949, as amended: MCL 257.716 through MCL 257.726b, which provisions are hereby adopted by reference, including, but not limited to, all provisions relating to fines and costs imposed thereunder for weight and all other violations; provided, however, that the penalty for a violation of the criminal provisions of this article shall not exceed a fine of $500.00, or imprisonment for 90 days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 6, 8-21-95) 
Chapter 90 - TREES AND VEGETATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 62; zoning, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City superintendent or superintendent means the city superintendent or his representative designated for purposes of the enforcement of this chapter. 
    Park means all public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access. 
    Public utility means any person, organization, firm or corporation, public or private, duly authorized to supply electric, gas, telephone, telegraph or water service to, or for the general benefit of, the public. 
    Right-of-way means any public street, highway, alley or avenue of the city. 
    Trees and shrubs means all woody vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 1, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-1; Ord. No. 210, § 1, 6-2-69; Ord. No. 286, § 2, 1-6-75) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-2. - Applicability. 
    The terms of this chapter, unless otherwise specifically stated, shall apply only to public streets, alleys, highways, highway easements, parkways, parks and other land publicly owned or controlled by the city. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 2, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-2) 
Sec. 90-3. - Enforcement by department of public works. 
    The department of public works shall be charged with the duty of enforcing the provisions of this chapter and shall discharge all duties that may be required or imposed by the city superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 2, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-3) 
Sec. 90-4. - General control by superintendent in accordance with recommendations of parks and beautification commission. 
    The city superintendent shall have control over all trees, shrubs and plants in the streets, alleys and parks of the city and is empowered to plant, prune, spray, cultivate and preserve all trees and shrubs within the confines of the streets, alleys, parks and public areas of the city in accordance with written recommendations duly made by the parks and beautification commission. In areas of policy or procedure where the parks and beautification commission has failed to make a written recommendation, the city superintendent shall have the authority to exercise his own discretion; provided, however, that in areas where such written recommendations have been made by the parks and beautification commission, they shall be followed by the city superintendent, unless overruled by the council. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 3, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-4; Ord. No. 210, § 2, 6-2-69) 
Sec. 90-5. - Permission required to prune, spray, plant, remove. 
    No person shall prune, spray, plant or remove any shrubs or trees upon the rights-of-way or parks without first obtaining a written permit from the city superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 3, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-5) 
Sec. 90-6. - Permit required to cut, break down, destroy. 
    No person shall cut or break down or destroy any trees or shrubs in the rights-of-way or parks at any time without first obtaining the written permission of the city superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 3, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-6) 
Sec. 90-7. - Planting regulated. 
    No person shall plant any shade or ornamental trees in the rights-of-way or parks except by permission of the superintendent, and then only if they are of a variety or size acceptable to the department of public works. In no event shall any tree be planted in the rights-of-way where police, fire, street lighting, traffic signal or public utility, overhead wires and equipment are located that will exceed a maximum growth of 40 feet. No person shall have the right to plant any variety of poplar, willows, box elders, soft maples, tree of heaven, prickly ash, wild chestnut, cottonwood or other quick-growing trees in such a location that their roots are likely to injure sewers or heave walk or street surfaces. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 3, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-7; Ord. No. 438, § 1, 3-20-89) 
Sec. 90-8. - Fastening things to trees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any tree as an anchor, and no material shall be fastened to or hung on any tree in any rights-of-way or park. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 4, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-8) 
Sec. 90-9. - Excavations, driveways near trees. 
    Excavations and driveways shall not be placed within six feet of any tree without written permit from the city superintendent or his authorized agent. Any person making such excavation or construction shall guard any tree within six feet thereof with a good substantial frame box to be approved by the department of public works, and all building material or other debris shall be kept at least four feet from any tree. All persons desiring to make such excavation or construction shall deposit with the city treasurer a sum sufficient to cover the cost of inspection and any damage which may result therefrom, provided that such charge shall not be less than $2.00 in any case. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 5, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-9) 
Sec. 90-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 773 , § 2, adopted Aug. 17, 2015, repealed § 90-10, which pertained to trimming of growths on private property and derived from Ord. No. 137, § 6, adopted Sept. 19, 1956; Code 1968, § 20-10; and Ord. No. 636, § 1, adopted Dec. 4, 2000. 
Sec. 90-11. - Placing materials on public property. 
    No person shall place on public property any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other material which will in any way impede the full and free passage of water, air or fertilizer to the roots of any tree subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 7, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-11) 
Sec. 90-12. - Protection from gas leaks. 
    Gas pipes or mains within any public right-of-way or on any public property shall be so maintained as to avoid any leakage therefrom. In the event a leak exists or occurs, it shall be reported to the owner of such pipe and main, and the leak shall be repaired within 24 hours. Any damage to trees, shrubbery or grass resulting from the escape of gas from a pipe or main shall be repaired and the cost of the work, including the cost or removal and the replacement of any trees, shall be levied against the owner of the pipe or main causing the damage. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 8, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-12) 
Sec. 90-13. - Damaging generally. 
    No person shall break, injure, mutilate, kill or destroy any tree or shrub, or set any fire or permit any fire, or the heat thereof, to injure any portion of any tree. No toxic chemicals or other injurious materials shall be allowed to seep, drain or be emptied on, near or about any tree; provided, however, that this shall not prohibit the use of city approved chemical control of trees and brush growth. No electric wires or installation, or any other lines or wires shall be attached to any tree in any manner that shall cause damage thereto. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 9, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-13) 
Sec. 90-14. - Interfering with trimming or removal. 
    All persons having under their care, custody or control, facilities which may interfere with the trimming or removal of any tree subject to this chapter, shall, after notice thereof by the city superintendent, promptly abate such interference in such a manner as shall permit the trimming or removal of any tree by the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 9, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-14) 
Sec. 90-15. - When planting, removal may be done by city in public places. 
    The planting or removal of trees and shrubs in the public rights-of-way, parkways, parks and other public areas of the city may be done either upon resolution of the city council or petition of parties owning a majority of the lineal footage of the property fronting on the line of such street. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 10, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-15) 
Sec. 90-16. - Superintendent to recommend planting, removal; special assessments. 
    Whenever deemed necessary by the city superintendent to lay out and plant trees and shrubs upon any public rights-of-way within the city or to remove undesirable species of trees, other than those so specified in this article, it shall be the duty of the city superintendent to report such fact to the city council. Such planting or removal shall be deemed to be a public improvement. The cost thereof may be paid, in whole or in part, by levying and collecting special assessments upon property especially benefited thereby in accordance with the provisions in the charter governing special assessments. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 11, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-16) 
Charter reference- Special assessments, § 9.5. 
Sec. 90-17. - Spacing, location of trees. 
(a)  In all planting of shade trees in the rights-of-way, such trees shall be spaced not less than 50 feet apart, except that trees may be planted less than 50 feet from an existing tree in the rights-of-way, provided the existing tree has been approved for removal within a period of two years from the date of planting of the new tree, and except that in exceptional cases, any owner of a single lot may, in order to provide a shade or ornamental tree in front of his lot, secure special permission from the department of public works to have a tree planted closer than 50 feet from an existing tree, but in no case shall such planting be within 30 feet of any existing tree on the rights-of-way. 
(b)  No tree shall be planted in planting strips between the curb and sidewalk less than 21/2 feet from the sidewalk; trees on private property adjacent to the sidewalk shall be planted not less than three feet therefrom. No trees shall be planted in planting strips where the distance between the back of the curb and the sidewalk is less than four feet, six inches in width. No trees shall be planted nearer to the intersection of any two or more streets than 25 feet from the point of intersection of two rights-of-way lines. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 12, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-17) 
Sec. 90-18. - Authority to remove undesirable trees, shrubs. 
(a)  The city superintendent is hereby authorized to direct the department of public works to remove any undesirable trees or shrubs growing on any rights-of-way, park or public place in the city, after approval of such removal by the parks and beautification commission. 
(b)  The city superintendent is hereby authorized to direct the department of public works to remove any trees or shrubs growing on any rights-of-way, park or public place in the city when such trees or shrubs are interfering with fire hydrants, sewers and water mains, visibility at street intersections, traffic control devices or construction affecting the public health and safety within rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 137, §§ 15, 16, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-18; Ord. No. 210, § 3, 6-2-69) 
Sec. 90-19. - Removal of trees-Dead, diseased. 
    All dead trees and trees afflicted with any fatal or communicable disease shall be removed by the department of public works with the approval of the city forester, or such other tree expert as the city superintendent shall deem appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 13, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-19; Ord. No. 210, § 4, 6-2-69; Ord. No. 607, § 1, 11-9-98) 
Sec. 90-20. - Same-At request of property owner. 
(a)  Living trees may be removed in accordance with the requirements of this chapter, when the owner of the property in front of which the tree is situated requests in writing the removal of such tree and the parks and beautification commission approves of such removal. 
(b)  Where an owner of property requests the removal of a tree the superintendent is authorized, in his discretion, to require as a condition precedent to granting of approval for such removal that such property owner make the removal in accordance with regulations established by the department of public works, assume all or any part of the costs of removing such tree, and also to further require that such tree be replaced at some other location in the immediate vicinity, by planting another tree of a type permitted under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 13, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-20; Ord. No. 210, § 5, 6-2-69) 
Sec. 90-21. - Notice, hearing on removal of trees. 
    The abutting property owner shall be notified in the event of the intended removal of any living tree. In the event of an objection from the abutting property owners, the trees shall not be removed until after a public hearing has been held by the city council to consider its removal. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 13, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-21) 
Sec. 90-22. - Control, trimming by utilities. 
    The city clerk shall, upon request of any interested public utility, issue an annual permit, and shall annually thereafter renew such permit, granting permission to the public utility to chemically control and trim and keep trimmed all trees and shrubs intruding into the air space over, or growing within the confines of, the streets, alleys, parks, rights-of-way and public places of the city in such a manner as shall keep the overhead lines and equipment of the public utility safe and accessible, and clear of all tree growth which endangers or may endanger the overhead lines or equipment and the public health and safety. Such chemical control and trimming shall be done in accordance with approved practices and under the general direction of the superintendent. The permit, as provided for in this section, shall require reasonable prior notice to the city before any work is commenced thereunder. In the event of an emergency requiring immediate maintenance work on the overhead lines of the public utility, prior notice of commencing work under the permit shall not be required. The word "emergency" as used in this section, shall be defined to mean the occurrence or happening of an event which could not be expected or prevented by the exercise of reasonable care and foresight and which endangers or may endanger the overhead lines of the public utilities and the public health and safety. 
(Ord. No. 137, § 14, 9-19-56; Code 1968, § 20-22) 
Secs. 90-23-90-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRIMMING AND REMOVAL OF TREES AND SHRUBS ON PRIVATE PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 773 , § 1, adopted Aug. 17, 2015, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 90-46-90-49, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to diseased and infested plants and derived from Ord. No. 130, §§ 2-5, adopted Feb. 1, 1954 and Code 1968, §§ 20-33-20-36. 

Sec. 90-46. - Definitions. 
    These words and phrases shall have the following meanings when used in this article: 
    Actual cost means labor, material, equipment, and contractor costs incurred by the city. 
    Issuance of the notice means any of the following events: 
(1)  The posting of the notice on the premises, in conjunction with the mailing of the notice to the responsible party's last known address; 
(2)  The responsible party's receipt of the notice by email, as indicated in a notification of receipt; 
(3)  Personal delivery of the notice to the responsible party; 
(4)  The responsible party's receipt of the notice by certified U.S. mail, as indicated in a notification of receipt; or 
(5)  The reading of the notice to the responsible party over the phone. 
    Property owner means a person who holds record title to a parcel of real estate. 
    Responsible party generally means the property owner, except that: 
(1)  A tenant or other person shall be a responsible party (in addition to the property owner) upon expressly assuming responsibility in a written contract with the property owner; and 
(2)  The manager of a business shall be a responsible party (in addition to the property owner) with respect to the property on which the business is situated. For purposes of this section, the term "manager" means the individual that exercises the most control over the day-to-day operations of the business on the property. 
(Ord. No. 773 , § 1, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 90-47. - Duty to maintain trees and shrubs. 
    The responsible party for each private property in the city shall: 
(1)  Trim the branches of any tree, shrub or plant on the property so that the branches: 
a.  Do not obstruct the view of any street intersection or traffic control device. 
b.  Do not interfere or threaten to interfere with any utility facilities owned by the city or a private utility company with a franchise granted by the city. 
c.  Remain at least 12 inches from the vertical plane drawn from the edge of the sidewalk (or from the edge of the right-of-way where no sidewalk exists), except that the branches may extend over the sidewalk at a height of nine feet or higher and over the rest of the right-of-way at a height of 16 feet or higher. 
(2)  Spray, trim, or otherwise treat diseased or infested trees, shrubs, or plants on the property. 
(3)  Remove any diseased or infested trees, shrubs, or plants on the property when necessary to prevent the spread of disease or infestation. 
(4)  Remove any dead trees, shrubs, or plants standing on the property. 
(5)  Remove fallen branches from any tree on the property from public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 773 , § 1, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 90-48. - Municipal civil infraction. 
    A responsible party that violates this article shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction, and any violating condition shall be considered a public nuisance. The city reserves the right to seek a court order authorizing city personnel to perform work needed to abate the nuisance at the responsible party's expense, with the cost of performing the work being a lien on the property. 
(Ord. No. 773 , § 1, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 90-49. - Abatement notice. 
(a)  Issuance and abatement period. In addition or in the alternative to pursuing a municipal civil infraction violation, the city may issue a notice stating that the city plans to abate a condition in violation of this article at the responsible party's expense if the responsible party fails to do so within seven days of the issuance of the notice, or, if the condition poses an imminent threat to public health or safety, within 24 hours of the issuance of the notice. 
(b)  Expedient means of providing notice. In cases where the property appears to be vacant, the city shall make reasonable efforts to notify the responsible party by expedient means other than posting the notice on the property (i.e. telephone or email, if reasonably available). The city shall also use expedient means of providing notice in cases where the responsible party has specifically requested that it do so by providing a telephone number or email address to the city superintendent. 
(c)  Contents of notice. The notice shall state the name of the individual or entity that the city considers to be the responsible party, and shall state the means of abatement that the city considers to be necessary (e.g. spraying, trimming, or removal). In cases where the superintendent considers removal to be necessary but not imminent, the removal notice shall inform the recipient of the right to request a hearing before the city superintendent (or, if the superintendent was involved in issuing the abatement notice, the city manager), within three days of the issuance of the notice, to show cause as to why the tree should not be removed. 
(Ord. No. 773 , § 1, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 90-50. - Recovery of costs. 
    If the responsible party fails to remedy the conditions cited in an abatement notice within the specified time period, the city may perform the work and bill the responsible party for the actual cost of the work, plus an administrative fee of ten percent. The bill shall inform the recipient of the right to request a hearing before the city superintendent (or, if the superintendent was involved in issuing the abatement notice, the city manager), within 15 days of the issuance of the bill, to show cause as to why the person receiving the bill should not be held financially responsible for the cost of the work. 
(Ord. No. 773 , § 1, 8-17-15) 
Secs. 90-51-90-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GRASS AND WEEDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 768 , § 1, adopted March 16, 2015, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 90-71-90-74, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to noxious weeds and derived from Ord. No. 142, §§ 1-4, adopted June 3, 1957; Code 1968, §§ 23-1-23-4; Ord. No. 226, § 1, adopted Aug. 16, 1971; Ord. No. 339, § 1, adopted Aug. 6, 1979; and Ord. No. 620, § 1, adopted Dec. 20, 1999. 

Sec. 90-71. - Definitions. 
    These words and phrases shall have the following meanings when used in this article: 
    Ground-cover vegetation means any of a variety of low-growing or trailing plants used to cover patches of ground. 
    Issuance of the notice means any of the following events: 
(1)  The posting of the notice on the premises, in conjunction with the mailing of the notice to the responsible party's last known address; 
(2)  The responsible party's receipt of the notice by email, as indicated in a notification of receipt; 
(3)  Personal delivery of the notice to the responsible party; 
(4)  The responsible party's receipt of the notice by certified U.S. mail, as indicated in a notification of receipt; or 
(5)  The reading of the notice to the responsible party over the phone. 
    Noxious weeds means the following plants only: Canada thistle (Cirsium arvense), dodders (any species of Cuscuta), mustards (charlock, black mustard, and Indian mustard, species of Brassica or Sinapis), wild carrot (Daucus carota), bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis), perennial sowthistle (Sonchus arvensis), hoary alyssum (Berteroa incana), giant hogweed (Heracleum mantegazzianum), ragweed (Ambrosia elatior I.), and poison ivy (Rhus toxicodendron), and poison sumac (Toxicodendron vernix). 
    Property owner means a person who holds record title to a parcel of real estate. 
    Responsible party generally means the property owner, except that: 
(1)  A tenant or other person shall be a responsible party (in addition to the property owner) upon expressly assuming responsibility in a written contract with the property owner; and 
(2)  The manager of a business shall be a responsible party (in addition to the property owner) with respect to the property on which the business is situated. For purposes of this section, the term "manager" means the individual that exercises the most control over the day-to-day operations of the business on the property. 
(Ord. No. 768 , § 1, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 90-72. - Duty to remove noxious weeds and maintain grass. 
    The responsible party for each private property in the city shall be required to keep the property free from noxious weeds and (except as provided in section 90-74) ensure that grass and other ground-cover vegetation on the property does not grow in excess of seven inches in height. The duties established under this section extend to the portions of the abutting public right-of-way that would become part of the property if the right-of-way were vacated. The responsible party shall have discretion in determining how to landscape and maintain the vegetation in the abutting right-of-way, so long as the landscaping and maintenance complies with all applicable laws, regulations, and ordinances and so long as it does not overhang any sidewalk or other public way in a manner that will interfere or brush against any person using that public way and as long as it does not interfere with the clear vision of vehicle drivers or pedestrians entering and exiting the property. 
(Ord. No. 768 , § 1, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 90-73. - Burning of vegetation prohibited. 
    No person shall intentionally burn grasses, weeds, shrubs, bushes, or other vegetation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 768 , § 1, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 90-74. - Natural landscaping. 
    This article shall not prohibit a responsible party from maintaining a natural lawn consisting of historically native grasses or other ground-cover vegetation exceeding seven inches in height, so long as the vegetation does not create a public nuisance, does not overhang into the right-of-way or impair visibility, and does not violate section 90-10 or any other city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 768 , § 1, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 90-75. - Municipal civil infraction. 
    A responsible party that violates this article or violates the conditions of a natural landscaping permit shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. Each day that the prohibited condition continues shall be a separate offense. For single-family residences, the first offense in each spring/summer season shall be punished by a fine of $25.00, the second offense shall be punished by a fine of $100.00, and each offense thereafter shall be punished by a fine of $200.00. For all properties other than single-family residences, the first offense in each spring/summer season shall be punished by a fine of $100.00, the second offense shall be punished by a fine of $250.00, and each offense thereafter shall be punished by a fine of $500.00. The city also reserves the right to seek a court order authorizing city personnel to remove noxious weeds or cut grass at the responsible party's expense, with the cost of performing the work being a lien on the property. 
(Ord. No. 768 , § 1, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 90-76. - Removal notice. 
    In addition or in the alternative to pursuing a municipal civil infraction violation, the city may issue a notice stating that the city plans to remove noxious weeds or cut grass at the responsible party's expense if the responsible party fails to do so within 48 hours of the issuance of the notice. The notice shall state the name of the individual or entity that the city considers to be the responsible party. In cases where the property appears to be vacant, the city shall make reasonable efforts to notify the responsible party by expedient means other than posting the notice on the property (i.e. telephone or email, if reasonably available). The city shall also use expedient means of providing notice in cases where the responsible party has specifically requested that it do so by providing a telephone number or email address to the city superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 768 , § 1, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 90-77. - Recovery of costs. 
    If the responsible party fails to remedy the conditions cited in a removal notice within 48 hours of the issuance of the notice, the city may perform the work and bill the responsible party for a fee in an amount established by the city council from time to time. The city reserves the bill the responsible party for the actual cost of performing the work (instead of the otherwise applicable fee) in cases where the cost of the work are unusually high due to the size of the property, severity of the conditions, etc. The bill shall inform the recipient of the right to request a hearing before the city superintendent (or, if the superintendent was involved in issuing the removal notice, the city manager), within 15 days of the issuance of the bill, to show cause as to why the person receiving the bill should not be held financially responsible for the cost of the work. 
(Ord. No. 768 , § 1, 3-16-15) 
Chapter 94 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; planning, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and public improvements, ch. 74; subdivisions, ch. 78; zoning, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec 94-1. - Rates, fees, and charges. 
    The method for establishing the following rates, fees, and charges and the amounts of such rates, fees, and charges shall be set from time to time by resolution of the city council in a manner consistent with this section. 
(1)  Water and sewer service. The city shall bill its customers for water and sewer service at least once per quarter at rates sufficient to satisfy the financial obligations of the water and sewer system, including debt service. The rates for water and sewer service shall consist of at least two components: a readiness-to-serve charge and a consumption charge. 
(2)  Second meter option. Users may request permission from the city manager to install a water meter at the user's sole expense to measure the water that is not discharged into the city's sanitary sewer system. When such meter has been installed with the permission of the city manager, the user shall not be charged for sanitary sewer service for the portion of water that is not discharged into the sanitary sewer system. The city manager shall develop criteria for considering requests to install such meters and shall only grant permission in cases where a substantial amount of the water consumed by the user bypasses the sanitary sewer system. 
(3)  Fire hydrant charge. For water used through fire hydrants and for the availability of such water, the city shall pay a fixed charge based on the number of fire hydrants located in the city. The city shall pay this charge at least once per quarter, in advance, from the proceeds of taxes levied for that purpose. 
(4)  Extra strength sewer charge. All users with extra strength sewage shall be assessed a surcharge based on the loading of the following compatible pollutants: 
a.  Biological oxygen demand (BOD). 
b.  Suspended solids (SS). 
c.  Phosphorus. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 10, 8-30-54; Ord. No. 159, § 1, 3-19-62; Code 1968, § 22-11; Ord. No. 241, § 1, 5-15-72; Ord. No. 251, §§ 1, 2, 9-18-72; Ord. No. 272, § 1, 5-21-74; Ord. No. 281, § 1, 12-2-74; Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-2-80; Ord. No. 369, § 1, 6-21-82; Ord. No. 387, § 1, 6-18-84; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 8-19-85; Ord. No. 421, § 1, 12-21-87; Ord. No. 518, § 1, 10-18-93; Ord. No. 527, § 1, 7-11-94; Ord. No. 571, § 1, 5-20-96; Ord. No. 637, § 1, 11-20-00; Ord. No. 671, § 1, 8-25-03; Ord. No. 707, § 1, 6-18-07; Ord. No. 724, § 1, 8-3-09; Ord. No. 726, § 1, 12-7-09; Ord. No. 754 , § 1, 1-13-14) 
Sec. 94-2. - Billing; when charges due; delinquency penalty. 
(a)  Billing for water and sewer charges shall be made on or before the first day of the month quarterly, bimonthly, or monthly as determined from time to time by resolution of the city council and shall be due and payable on the first city business day (i.e. a day on which the city hall is open and staffed) of the following month, except on Saturday, Sunday, or holiday. 
(b)  For all bills not paid when due, a late payment fee, interest and an administrative fee shall be added, as specified by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 10, 8-30-54; Ord. No. 159, § 2, 3-19-62; Code 1968, § 22-12; Ord. No. 421, § 2, 12-21-87; Ord. No. 633, § 1, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 704, § 1, 4-16-07; Ord. No. 752 , § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 94-3. - Connection permit charges. 
(a)  In order to assure sufficient revenues to pay for improvements, enlargements, extensions and repairs from time to time to the water supply system and sewage disposal system of the city and in addition to the actual cost of labor and materials for each connection to the water supply system or the sewage disposal system of the city, a connection permit charge shall be levied against every property newly connected to the systems to provide the property's fair share of the cost of additions to the systems resulting from service demand growth or from additional connections to the systems, and to bear its fair share of the amortized cost of the existing improvements not financed by special assessment. The connection permit charge shall become payable at the time of occupancy at the rates set forth in this section.

(e)  A reduced water and sewer connection permit charge may be provided for by council resolution for multiple residence facilities such as homes for the elderly, other than foster care facilities, which can be shown to use less water and sewer by design and/or usage than provided for by this ordinance with the reduction in said charge to be in proportion to such reduced design and/or usage. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 10, 8-30-54; Ord. No. 159, § 3, 3-19-62; Ord. No. 165, § 1, 4-4-63; Ord. No. 170, § 1, 12-16-63; Code 1968, § 22-13; Ord. No. 241, § 2, 5-15-72; Ord. No. 246, § 1, 7-17-72; Ord. No. 271, § 1, 5-6-74; Ord. No. 301, § 1, 5-19-76; Ord. No. 409, § 1, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 8-21-95; Ord. No. 562, § 1, 1-15-96; Ord. No. 564, § 1, 2, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 571, §§ 2, 3, 5-20-96; Ord. No. 592, § 1, 5-18-98; Ord. No. 696, § 1, 9-18-06; Ord. No. 740, § 1, 5-21-12) 
Sec. 94-4. - Meter sizing, installation, and ownership. 
(a)  All meters shall be supplied by the city and shall remain the property of the city after installation thereof. The actual cost of all meters, meter parts, and installation labor, for all meters installed after the effective date of this ordinance shall be charged to the user, and no water shall be turned on to be measured by such city owned and supplied meters until such actual costs have been paid in full by the user to the city. The actual cost of repair or replacement thereof resulting from negligent use or care thereof shall be charged against the user as an additional charge on the next water and/or sewer bill sent to the user. In all cases where water is turned on or turned off, either at the request of the user or for nonpayment of charges, and in all cases where a meter is installed or removed by the city, at the owner's request, a reasonable service charge to be established by the city council shall be made. Such service charge shall be charged to the user as an additional charge on the next water and sewer bill sent to the user. Maintenance expense on such city owned and supplied meters shall be charged against the user as part of the regular rates to be charged for water and sewer service. 
(b)  Applicants requesting the installation of a water meter, in other than a one- and two-family structure, shall submit the following information to the code official: meter installation drawings signed and sealed by a design professional; meter design calculations in accordance with the adopted plumbing code. 
(c)  The use of multiple water meters for a single facility or building must be reviewed and approved by the city. 
(d)  No meter size shall be changed unless approved by the city. Sizing shall be determined and approved as required in subsection (b). The property owner shall reimburse the city for costs incurred by the city to change the meter, including the cost of any required plumbing inspection. When an increase in meter size is approved for any nonresidential structure, the property owner shall pay a connection fee equal to the difference in the connection charges listed in section 94-3. When a decrease in meter size is approved, no refund of connection charge will be considered, and the newly installed meter size becomes the size of record. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 4, 3-19-62; Code 1968, § 22-14; Ord. No. 628, § 1, 4-17-00; Ord. No. 697, § 1, 10-16-06) 
Sec. 94-5. - Lien for delinquent charges; enforcement; deposit required. 
    The charges for water and sewer services which are under the provisions of section 21, Act No. 94 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1933 (MCL 141.120 et seq.), as amended, made a lien on all premises served thereby, unless notice is given that a tenant is responsible, are hereby recognized to constitute such lien and whenever any such charge against any piece of property shall be delinquent for six months the city official or officials in charge of the collection thereof shall certify annually, on July 1 of each year, to the tax assessing officer of the city, the fact of such delinquency, whereupon such charge shall be by him entered upon the next tax roll as a charge against such premises and shall be collected and the lien thereof enforced in the same manner as general city taxes against such premises are collected, and the lien thereof enforced; provided, however, where notice is given that a tenant is responsible for such charges and service as provided by section 21 no further service shall be rendered to such premises until the cash deposit of not less than the amount of the estimated bill for such service for one quarter for a like use as determined by the city treasurer shall have been made as security for payment of such charges and service. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 10, 8-30-54; Code 1968, § 22-15; Ord. No. 252, § 1, 10-2-72) 
Sec. 94-6. - Discontinuing service for nonpayment; charge for resuming service. 
    In addition to other remedies provided, the city shall have the right to shut off and discontinue the supply of water and sewer service to any premises for the nonpayment of water and sewer rates when due. If such charges are not paid within 30 days after the due date thereof, then water and sewer services to such premises shall be discontinued. Water and sewer services so discontinued shall not be restored until all sums then due and owing shall be paid, plus a turn-on charge as established by resolution of the Saline City Council. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 10, 8-30-54; Code 1968, § 22-16; Ord. No. 541, § 1, 9-19-94) 
Sec. 94-7. - Special sewage; right to charge extra, require treatment. 
    If the character of sewage from any manufacturing or industrial plant or any other building or premises shall be such as to impose an unreasonable additional burden upon the sewers of the water supply and sewage disposal system, an additional charge may be made over and above the regular rates, or it may be required that such sewage be treated by the person responsible therefor before being emptied into the sewer, or the right to empty such sewage may be denied if necessary for the protection of the sewer and sewage disposal facilities of the system or the public health or safety. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 12, 8-30-54; Code 1968, § 22-18) 
Sec. 94-8. - Deposit, use of revenues-Wastewater user charges. 
(a)  Wastewater enterprise funds. All revenues collected from the user charge shall be set aside as collected and deposited in a separate depository account in a bank duly qualified to do business in Michigan and insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. The deposit shall be in an account to be designated as a wastewater enterprise fund and the revenue so deposited shall be pledged for the purpose of operation, maintenance and replacement of the wastewater collection and treatment system. 
(b)  Wastewater operation and maintenance fund. Out of the revenues generated from the wastewater enterprise fund, there shall be set aside monthly amounts into a separate depository account designated as wastewater operation and maintenance funds, with the sum deposited being sufficient to provide for the payment of the next month's current expenses of administration and operation of the system, and such current expenses for the maintenance thereof as may be necessary to preserve the same facilities in good repair and working order. 
(c)  Wastewater replacement fund. There shall be established and maintained a separate depository account designated as wastewater replacement fund which shall be used solely for the purpose of making major repairs and replacement to the wastewater collection and treatment system. There shall be deposited into the account in quarterly installments, after providing for all requirements of the wastewater operation and maintenance fund, an amount not less than $19,280.00 per quarter until such fund shall total $1,928,000.00. If at any time it shall be necessary to use the monies in said fund for such purposes as replacements to the system, the money so used shall be replaced from future revenues in the wastewater enterprise fund, which are not required for the wastewater operation and maintenance cost. 
(d)  City council review. The city council shall, on an annual basis, review the balances in the wastewater operation and maintenance fund and in the wastewater replacement fund to examine the amount of funds available and any fund balance that has accumulated. These funds shall be used for no other purposes than those designated. Monies which have been transferred from other sources to meet temporary shortages in the operation, maintenance and replacement funds shall be returned to their respective accounts upon appropriate adjustments to the user charge rates for operation, maintenance and replacement. The user charge rate shall be adjusted such that the transferred monies will be returned to their respective accounts within six months of the fiscal year in which the monies were borrowed. 
(e)  Budget. The city council, prior to the commencement of each operating year, shall adopt a budget covering the foregoing expenses for each year and such total expenses shall not exceed the total amount specified in the budget, except by a vote of three-fifths of the members of the city council. 
(Code 1968, § 22-19; Ord. No. 408, § 2, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 94-9. - Same-Water user charges. 
(a)  Water enterprise funds. All the revenues collected from user charge shall be set aside as collected and deposited in a separate depository account in a bank duly qualified to do business in Michigan and insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. The deposit shall be in an account to be designated as water enterprise fund, and the revenue so deposited shall be pledged for the purpose of operation, maintenance and replacement of the water production and distribution system. 
(b)  Water operation and maintenance fund. Out of the revenues generated from the water enterprise fund, there shall be set aside monthly amounts into a separate depository account designated as water operation and maintenance funds, with the sum deposited being sufficient to provide for the payment of the next month's current expenses of the administration and operation of the system, and such current expenses for the maintenance thereof as may be necessary to preserve the same facilities in good repair and working order. 
(c)  Water replacement fund. There shall be established and maintained a separate depository account designated as water replacement fund which shall be used solely for the purpose of making major repairs and replacement to the water production and distribution system. There shall be deposited into said account in quarterly installments, after providing for all requirements of the water operation and maintenance fund, an amount of not less than $2,500.00 per quarter until such fund shall total $100,000.00. If at any time it shall be necessary to use the monies in the fund for such purposes as replacements to the system, the money so used shall be replaced from future revenues in the water enterprise fund, which are not required for the water operation and maintenance cost. 
(d)  City council review. The city council shall, on an annual basis, review the balances in the water operation and maintenance fund and in the water replacement fund to examine the amount of funds available and any fund balance that has accumulated. These funds shall be used for no other purposes than those designated. Monies which have been transferred from other sources to meet temporary shortages in the operation, maintenance and replacement funds shall be returned to their respective accounts upon appropriate adjustments of the service charge rates for operation, maintenance and replacement. The use charge rate shall be adjusted such that the transferred monies will be returned to their respective accounts within six months of the fiscal year in which the monies were borrowed. 
(e)  Budget. The city council, prior to the commencement of each operating year shall adopt a budget covering the foregoing expenses for each year and such total expenses shall not exceed the total amount specified in the budget, except by a vote of three-fifths of the members of the city council. 
(Code 1968, § 22-20; Ord. No. 408, § 2, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 94-10. - Equal operation, maintenance and repair rates. 
    Equal operation, maintenance and repair rates, proportionate to use, shall be charged to all users of the system, inside and outside the city. 
(Code 1968, § 22-21; Ord. No. 418, § 1, 11-23-87) 
Sec. 94-11. - Annual notification to users of breakdown of charges. 
    The city shall at least annually notify each user of the system of the breakdown of charges into debt service, replacement, and operation, maintenance and repair (OM&R) components. 
(Code 1968, § 22-22; Ord. No. 418, § 1, 11-23-87) 
Sec. 94-12. - Shutting off water service from portion of city; notice. 
    Should it become necessary to shut off water from any section of the city because of accidents or for the purpose of making repairs or extensions, the city will endeavor to give timely notice to the consumers affected thereby and will, so far as practical, use its best efforts to prevent inconvenience and damage arising from any such causes, but the failure to give such notice shall not render the city responsible or liable for damages which may result therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 7, 8-6-34; Code 1968, § 22-29) 
Sec. 94-13. - Cross connections. 
(a)  The city adopts by reference the water supply cross connection rules of the state department of environmental quality being R 325.11401 to R 325.11407. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city superintendent to cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water supply where cross connections with the public water supply is deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the city superintendent and as approved by the state department of environmental quality. 
(c)  The representative of the city superintendent shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply system of the city for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems thereof for cross connections. On request the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the inspection agency any pertinent information regarding the piping system or systems on such property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross connections. 
(d)  The city superintendent is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue water service after reasonable notice to any property wherein any connection in violation of this section exists, and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply system. Water service to such property shall not be restored until the cross connection has been eliminated in compliance with the provisions of this section. All testable backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested initially upon installation to be sure that the assembly is working properly. Subsequent testing of assemblies shall be tested on an annual basis as required by the city and in accordance with state department of environmental quality requirements. Only individuals that are approved and state certified shall be qualified to perform such testing. That individual(s) shall certify the results of his/her testing. 
(e)  The potable water supply made available on the properties served by the public water supply shall be protected from possible contamination as specified by this section and by the state and the city plumbing code. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as: 
WATER UNSAFE 
FOR DRINKING 
(f)  This section does not supersede the state plumbing code and existing city ordinances but is supplementary to them. 
(g)  Any person or customer found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section, or any written order of the city superintendent, in pursuance thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each violation. Each day upon which a violation of the provisions of this section shall occur shall be deemed a separate and additional violation for the purpose of this section. 
(Code 1968, § 22-30; Ord. No. 256, §§ 1-7, 5-7-73; Ord. 706, §§ 1-3, 5-21-07) 
Sec. 94-14. - Wells. 
(a)  All water wells shall comply with MCL 333.12701 et seq. 
(b)  This Code shall not restrict a registered well drilling contractor or registered pump installer, registered under MCL 333.12701 et seq., from engaging in his legally recognized trade. 
(c)  The registered drilling contractor or pump installer may install either within or without both habitable structures or commercial buildings, such pumps, pressure tanks, pipes, fittings and controls as shall be necessary to properly operate, service and test the well and water system. 
(Code 1968, § 6-97; Ord. No. 454, § 1, 5-7-90) 
Sec. 94-15. - Maintenance and repair of water service. 
    The cost of all repair, maintenance, and replacement of existing building water services, shutoffs, and their connection to the public water main, from the building to the city water main, shall be the responsibility of the property owner. Such owner shall make application to perform such work with the building department, and all work shall be in accordance with city codes and regulations. In the event the city requires emergency repair, or in the event that the property owner fails to make repairs, the city may make the repairs and charge the property owner for all actual costs. 
(Ord. No. 628, § 2, 4-17-00) 
Sec. 94-16. - Entry on premises-Failure to permit. 
    All property owners and/or persons in possession of premises served by city utilities shall permit authorized city officials to enter such premises for the purpose of installation, repair, maintenance, inspection, testing and/or meter reading of such utilities as necessary for the proper operation of such utilities, and failure to permit such entry shall subject such person or persons to discontinuance of service until compliance is obtained as well as such other penalties as are provided by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 652, § 1, 3-4-02) 
Secs. 94-17-94-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-36. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act, the act, Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Clean Water Act are used interchangeably in this article and refer to Public Law 92-500, as adopted in 1972 and amended by Public Law 95-217 in 1977, and any succeeding amendments. 
    Alternative discharge limit means limits set by the city in lieu of the promulgated national categorical pretreatment standards, for integrated facilities in accordance with the combined waste stream formula as set by the EPA. 
    Authorized representative of industrial user means: 
(1)  In the case of a corporation, a president, secretary, treasurer or vice president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function; 
(2)  In the case of a partnership or proprietorship, a general partner or proprietor; and
